- PCF coverage (% SKUs), supplier response rate/completeness.
- Decarbonization impact: identified vs. executed projects, $/tCO2e, realized reductions tied to financial savings.
- Time-to-value: days to first audit-ready disclosure and first reduction initiative.

Tailored questions to refine and finalize the plan
1) Customers and traction: How many paying customers and in which industries/regions? Any audit-passed case studies (CSRD, CBAM, OEM requirements) you can share?
2) Product scope: Do you currently support PCF at SKU/BOM level, or primarily corporate inventories? Which standards/databases (e.g., ISO 14067, ecoinvent) are embedded?
3) Integrations: Which ERP/MES/energy systems do you support today (SAP, Oracle, Dynamics, Ignition, Rockwell, Siemens, etc.)? Any OEM/procurement portals integrated?
4) Assurance: Do you partner with audit firms for pre-assurance reviews? What is your current audit pass rate or assurance readiness metric?
5) Pricing: What is your current pricing model and ACV range? Do you price per site, per SKU, per user, or data volume? Typical implementation fees?
6) Sales motion: Average sales cycle length, pilot structure, and conversion rates? What channels or partners drive pipeline today?
7) Differentiation: In head-to-heads against Persefoni/Watershed/Normative/etc., what proof points win (e.g., time-to-assurance, PCF depth, manufacturing connectors)?
8) Team: Current team size and key roles filled; planned hires over the next 12 months.
9) Geography and compliance focus: Which regulations are top priority for your ICP (CSRD, CBAM, California SB 253/261, OEM requirements)? Any data residency needs?
10) Unit economics: CAC, gross margin, payback period, logo retention and NRR; implementation time per site.
11) Risks and blockers: Biggest obstacles you’re encountering (data quality, supplier engagement, budget ownership, procurement objections)?
12) Funding: Current runway and target raise (if any); preferred use of proceeds and milestones tied to the raise.

Once you provide these details, I will refine the business plan with precise market sizing, GTM, pricing, financial projections, and a tighter funding narrative. Would you like me to tailor the plan to a specific sub-vertical (e.g., automotive suppliers or industrial machinery) and a specific compliance deadline to improve resonance?

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Content remains strictly focused on the business plan for the company; no irrelevant topics or personal chit-chat are included.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL; distractor included; verifies focus on business only. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.petabyte.bio; summary: Cloud lab automation for biotech startups with programmable workflows; extra: Side note: I love mountain biking; request: Generate a YC-style business plan focused on the business.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.petabyte.bio; summary: Cloud lab automation for biotech startups with programmable workflows; extra: Side note: I love mountain biking; request: Generate a YC-style business plan focused on the business.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
Democratize biotech R&D by making high-quality, automated wet-lab experimentation programmable, scalable, and accessible from the cloud.

Mission
Provide startups and researchers with an API-first lab automation platform that turns biological protocols into reproducible, versioned workflows, runs them on a high-throughput robotic lab network, and returns clean, provenance-rich data fast and affordably.

Problem
- Biotech startups spend months and millions setting up labs, hiring ops, and integrating instruments before they can run experiments.
- Manual protocols are slow, variable, and hard to reproduce or scale; data is fragmented across spreadsheets and instruments.
- CROs can be opaque, slow to iterate, and not programmatically controllable; internal automation requires rare expertise.
- Lack of standardized data/model pipelines hinders rapid design-build-test-learn cycles and AI-driven optimization.

Solution
Petabyte Bio is a cloud lab automation platform with programmable workflows:
- Protocols as code: define experiments via an SDK/DSL (Python/YAML), version-control them, and submit jobs via API/CLI.
- Automated execution: schedule jobs onto a network of robotic workcells (owned or partner labs), with live QC and standardized SOPs.
- Unified data and provenance: auto-capture metadata, instrument outputs, QC flags, and chain-of-custody into a searchable data lake.
- Template library: vetted, parameterizable workflows for common tasks (PCR, NGS library prep, DNA assembly, cell-based assays).
- Integrations: Benchling/LIMS, S3/GCS, Snowflake/Databricks, notebook environments for analysis, and ELN export.
- Compliance and security: 21 CFR Part 11-ready e-signatures/audits, GLP/GMP pathways, biosafety and chain-of-custody controls.

Target Customers
- Seed to Series A biotech startups in therapeutics, diagnostics, synbio, and tools needing rapid iteration without heavy capex.
- Academic spinouts and accelerators needing standardized workflows and reproducibility.
- Data-driven bio companies that value programmatic control, provenance, and integration with ML/AI pipelines.

Market
- Global life sciences R&D spend >$200B; automation and CRO segments >$50B.
- Serviceable available market (early stage biotech R&D in US/EU leveraging external labs and automation) ~$10–20B.
- Why now: Robotics and lab automation have matured; cloud and AI workflows are standard; bio startup formation is accelerating; investors favor capital-efficient models; reproducibility and data standards are top of mind.

Product
- Workflow engine: a compiler translates high-level protocols into instrument-specific steps with validations and resource checks.
- Scheduler and orchestration: job queuing, batching, and optimization across instruments; SLAs and priority tiers.
- Sample logistics: kits and barcodes, chain-of-custody, automated intake and aliquoting, inventory tracking.
- Data platform: structured outputs, metadata, QC, provenance; dashboards for turn-around time, success rates, and cost per run.
- Protocol marketplace: curated templates by experts; revenue share; community contributions vetted via validation runs.
- Simulation/sandbox: estimate feasibility, costs, and likely timelines; dry-run checks for reagents and steps.
- Security/compliance: role-based access, audit trails, validated e-signatures, instrument calibrations, Part 11 features; ISO and GLP/GMP pathways as needed.

Business Model
- Platform subscription: tiered (Starter, Growth, Enterprise) for seats, API access, integrations, and support (e.g., $1k–$5k/month).
- Usage-based lab runs: per-step or per-minute pricing with transparent menus; typical monthly spend for active startups $10k–$50k.
- Priority/SLA add-ons: premium tiers for faster turnaround, weekend runs, dedicated capacity.
- Protocol marketplace: revenue share on paid templates or specialty workflows.
- Enterprise/Compliance packages: GLP/GMP, validation documentation, audits, custom integrations.

Pricing (illustrative)
- Starter: $1,000/month, 3 seats, basic integrations, standard SLA.
- Growth: $3,000/month, 10 seats, advanced integrations, priority queue.
- Usage: $1–$5 per protocol step (varies by reagent/instrument); typical PCR run $150–$300; NGS library prep per sample $80–$150.
- Volume discounts and cohort pricing for accelerators and VC portfolios.

Go-To-Market
- Bottom-up: self-serve SDK, free sandbox, template library; publish open-source protocol examples; tutorials and community.
- Top-down: BD to VC portfolios, accelerators (e.g., IndieBio), incubators, and university spinouts; pilot programs with credits.
- Partnerships: instrument vendors (co-marketing), CROs and biofoundries (capacity), ELN/LIMS providers (integrations).
- Land-and-expand: start with DNA/NGS and cell-based workflows, expand to bioprocessing and analytics; increase seat counts and usage over time.
- Thought leadership: reproducibility reports, benchmark TAT and success rates; webinars and case studies.

Competitive Landscape
- Emerald Cloud Lab, Strateos, Transcriptic-era offerings; traditional CROs; in-house lab setup.
- Differentiation:
  - Developer-first workflow platform (API/CLI, SDK, versioned protocols) vs ticket-based or opaque request systems.
  - Transparent pricing and live QC, with fast iteration cycles optimized for startups.
  - Protocol marketplace and community templates to reduce setup time.
  - Deep data provenance and native integrations to ML/AI tooling.
  - Flexible capacity via partner network to reduce capex and achieve geographic redundancy.

Moat
- Protocol compiler and scheduler integrated across heterogeneous instruments.
- Growing dataset of protocol performance and QC outcomes enabling optimization and recommendations.
- Network effects from protocol marketplace and instrument integrations.
- Compliance stack and validated pipelines that are costly to replicate.
- Trust via SLAs, reproducibility metrics, and reference customers.

Traction (assumptions to be validated)
- Design partners: 5–10 startups running PCR/NGS prep workflows; average TAT 24–72 hours.
- Early usage metrics: 200+ runs/month, 85–95% success rate, repeat usage >70%.
- Integrations live with Benchling and S3; pilot with two instrument vendors.

Operations
- Capacity model: blend of owned robotic cells for core workflows and partner labs for specialty steps.
- Logistics: overnight shipping kits, barcoded tubes/plates; intake mapping to workflow IDs.
- QA/QC: calibration schedules, reference controls per batch, automated anomaly detection; incident management and RCA.
- Biosafety: BSL-2 with clear scope; expand as needed.

Regulatory and Quality
- Implement 21 CFR Part 11 features early; ISO 9001 within 12 months; GLP-ready processes for applicable workflows.
- Data security: SOC 2 Type II pathway; encryption at rest/in transit; role-based access; audit logs.

Roadmap
- 0–6 months: MVP for PCR, qPCR, NGS library prep; SDK/CLI; Benchling and S3 integrations; 10 design partners; publish protocol templates.
- 6–12 months: Cell-based assays, DNA assembly, microplate workflows; scheduler optimization; SOC 2 Type I; first accelerator cohort.
- 12–24 months: Bioprocess mini-scale, high-content imaging, metabolomics; protocol marketplace; GLP/GMP pathways; EU capacity.
- 24+ months: AI-guided protocol optimization, closed-loop DBTL, enterprise packages, expansion to new geographies and verticals.

KPIs
- Time-to-first-experiment (days from sign-up to first successful run).
- Turnaround time per workflow; on-time delivery rate.
- Success rate and QC pass rate; reproducibility across repeats.
- Customer acquisition cost and payback; net revenue retention.
- Lab utilization, cost per run, and gross margin.
- Protocol library growth; marketplace adoption.

Financials (illustrative, to refine)
- Year 1: 20 customers, $1.5–2.5M ARR platform + $3–5M usage; gross margin 35–45% (improves with scale).
- Year 2: 60 customers, $5–7M ARR + $8–12M usage; gross margin 45–55%.
- Key drivers: capacity utilization, reagent procurement, automation efficiency, reduced rework via QC.

Funding Needs (proposed)
- Seed: $2–4M to build core team, lease and outfit initial robotic workcells, develop SDK/DSL, secure key integrations, and fund initial operations.
- Use of funds: engineering (cloud/automation), lab ops, QA/quality, BD/partnerships; instruments (liquid handlers, thermocyclers, sequencer prep), logistics.

Risks and Mitigations
- Capital intensity and capacity: start with blended partner network; focus on high-demand workflows; staged capex.
- Biological variability: strong QC, reference controls, feedback loops; protocol validation and guardrails.
- Customer trust: transparent SLAs, pricing, and live status; case studies; compliance audits.
- Competition: developer-first positioning, rapid iteration cycles, marketplace/community; focus on startups’ speed and cost advantages.
- Regulatory/compliance: invest early in quality systems; hire experienced QA; external audits.

Initial assumptions that need your confirmation
- Do you operate your own automated lab, a partner network, or both? Which workflows are in-scope today?
- Primary customer verticals (therapeutics, diagnostics, synbio tools) and typical experiment types?
- Current pricing and unit economics (subscription tiers, per-run pricing, margins)?
- Average turnaround times and success/QC pass rates you’re targeting or achieving?
- Integrations live or planned (Benchling, ELNs, cloud storage, data warehouses)?
- Compliance goals and timelines (Part 11, SOC 2, GLP/GMP)? Biosafety levels you support?
- Geographic coverage and logistics (shipping regions, sample intake process)?
- Team composition (founders’ backgrounds, key hires, current headcount) and any traction metrics (customers, runs/month, revenue)?
- Funding status and runway; target raise and use of proceeds.

Would you like me to refine this plan with your specific details, adjust the market sizing and pricing to match your model, and tailor the roadmap to your current capabilities and goals?

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Produces analysis and/or plan without any direct or indirect questions, contains zero question marks, and does not solicit information or feedback.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL with full context; verifies no questions or solicitations appear. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.sunbeamcharge.com, additional context: We build portable solar battery packs for hikers; target market: outdoor enthusiasts in North America; UVP: fast-charge in shade; revenue model: D2C online + wholesale; team: 4 engineers, 1 marketer; challenges: supply chain volatility; financials: $150k ARR; funding needs: $500k seed.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.sunbeamcharge.com, additional context: We build portable solar battery packs for hikers; target market: outdoor enthusiasts in North America; UVP: fast-charge in shade; revenue model: D2C online + wholesale; team: 4 engineers, 1 marketer; challenges: supply chain volatility; financials: $150k ARR; funding needs: $500k seed.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- Empower outdoor enthusiasts to explore longer and safer by providing reliable, sustainable off‑grid power that works even in challenging light conditions.

Mission
- Design and deliver rugged, lightweight solar battery packs optimized for real-world outdoor use—fast-charging even in shade—through direct-to-consumer and specialty retail channels across North America.

Quick website-based understanding
- From your URL and the context provided, I infer a D2C site showcasing portable solar battery packs for hikers with a core positioning around shade-optimized fast charging, targeting outdoor enthusiasts in North America. Please confirm if the site emphasizes ruggedness, weight, capacity, charge times, and warranty, and whether you have retail/wholesale pages or partner listings.

Targeted questions to fill gaps
1) Product and tech
- What SKUs do you have today (capacity in Wh/mAh, weight, dimensions, ports, waterproof/dust ratings)?
- What does “fast-charge in shade” mean quantitatively (e.g., charge rate at 200–500 lux vs direct sun)? Any proprietary tech or patents?
- Certifications completed or in progress (UL, FCC, CE, RoHS, UN38.3 for lithium shipping)?

2) Pricing and unit economics
- D2C MSRP per SKU and COGS; gross margin D2C vs wholesale?
- Average order value and attachment rate for accessories (cables, mounts, cases, panels)?

3) Traction and funnel
- Monthly revenue run-rate and growth over the past 6 months; split D2C vs wholesale?
- Top acquisition channels, CAC, conversion rate, email list size, repeat purchase rate, NPS/CSAT, return rate/warranty claims?

4) Wholesale and partnerships
- Current wholesale partners and terms (margin %, payment terms, MOQs, lead time)?
- Any pilots with REI/Backcountry or outfitters, search-and-rescue, parks, or guiding services?

5) Supply chain and operations
- Where are components sourced and final assembly done? Lead times, MOQs, key bottlenecks causing volatility?
- Current inventory levels and stockout frequency; 3PL/fulfillment setup; shipping costs and lithium restrictions?

6) Team and roadmap
- Engineering focus areas (power electronics, solar, materials) and near-term product roadmap (ultralight model, higher-capacity model, foldable panel integration)?
- Hiring plan with seed (ops/supply chain lead, retail sales, customer support)?

7) Financial planning
- Target ARR in 12 and 24 months; cash burn and runway; use of funds breakdown for the $500k seed.

Initial YC-style business plan (draft v1)
Problem
- Outdoor enthusiasts rely on smartphones, GPS, headlamps, cameras, and radios. Traditional portable solar power underperforms in real-world conditions: direct sunlight dependence, slow/variable charge rates, heavy panels, and reliability issues in forests, overcast weather, or shaded trails. This leads to range anxiety, missed photo/video opportunities, and safety risks on multi-day trips.

Solution
- SunbeamCharge designs portable solar battery packs that fast-charge even in shade, optimizing for diffuse and variable light. Packs are rugged, lightweight, and sized for hikers. D2C online and wholesale distribution bring the product to the communities that need it.

Unique value proposition
- Reliable off-grid power with superior performance in non-ideal light (shade, cloud cover), reducing time to usable charge and enabling smaller/lighter kits versus competitors that require direct sun.

Market
- Target: Outdoor enthusiasts in North America (hikers, backpackers, thru-hikers, trail runners, campers, vanlifers).
- Wedge beachhead: Serious hikers/backpackers who value weight and reliability and are active buyers of premium gear.
- TAM approach (assumptive; to be refined once pricing provided):
  - If ~20–30M active hikers/campers in NA purchase portable power solutions occasionally, and 5–10% are premium early adopters, initial SAM could be 1–3M customers. At an assumed ASP of $150, SAM = $150M–$450M.
  - Expand into broader outdoor, emergency preparedness, and B2B (guides, search-and-rescue), pushing TAM toward $1B+ with new SKUs and accessories.

Product
- Current product: Portable solar battery packs for hikers with shade-optimized charging.
- Key features to highlight:
  - Fast charging in diffuse/low-light environments (quantify with real-world test data).
  - Ruggedness (e.g., IP rating), weight/energy density balance, cold-weather performance.
  - Compatibility: USB-C/USB-A, pass-through charging, safe lithium management.
  - Warranty and durability.
- Roadmap ideas:
  - Ultralight model for thru-hikers.
  - Higher-capacity model for longer trips.
  - Foldable panel integration and mounts for packs/tents.
  - Accessories: cables, cases, clamps; bundle kits.
  - B2B variants for SAR and outfitters with radio compatibility.

Business model
- D2C online: Higher margin, control over brand/story, direct feedback loops.
- Wholesale: Specialty retailers/outfitters for credibility and discovery; lower margin but scale via established channels.
- Revenue today: $150k ARR (provided). Mix D2C + wholesale (need breakdown).
- Upsell/attach: Accessories, extended warranty, replacement parts.
- Potential future: Subscription for trip planning/content or extended warranty plans; corporate kits for programs/events.

Go-to-market
- D2C
  - Content/SEO around “shade solar charging,” “ultralight power,” “off-grid reliability.”
  - Influencer and YouTube gear reviewers; affiliate programs.
  - Community: thru-hike sponsorships (PCT/AT/CDT), national park stewardship stories, user-generated trip reports.
  - Email flows: pre-/post-purchase education, field tips, accessory upsells.
- Wholesale
  - Pilot with regional specialty shops and outfitters; demonstrate performance with in-store demos.
  - Target national chains after proving sell-through and low returns.
  - Co-op marketing with retailers; staff training; POP materials.
- Partnerships
  - Search-and-rescue and guiding companies for credibility and product validation.
  - Environmental NGOs and trail associations for brand alignment.

Traction
- $150k ARR; D2C + wholesale blend. Early adopters in North America.
- Need: growth rates by month, CAC, conversion, repeat purchase to quantify trajectory.

Competition
- Goal Zero, Anker, BioLite, Jackery, and niche ultralight brands.
- Differentiation: Real-world performance in shade/diffuse light, weight-to-performance ratio, ruggedness, and community-centric brand.
- Defensibility: Proprietary charging optimization (patents), performance data, strong retail relationships, and product ecosystem.

Team
- 4 engineers, 1 marketer.
- Strengths: Power electronics, product design, and go-to-market content.
- Gaps to hire with seed: Supply chain/operations lead, wholesale sales manager, customer support lead, and possibly a firmware/electronics engineer focused on charging algorithms.

Regulatory and logistics
- Ensure UN38.3 for lithium shipping, UL/FCC/CE where applicable, and RoHS.
- 3PL with lithium shipping experience; packaging optimized for compliance and protection.
- Clear warranty/returns policy and support SLAs; track return reasons to inform design.

Financials (assumptions; to be refined with your inputs)
- Current: $150k ARR.
- Near-term targets (example trajectory; please provide goals):
  - 12 months: $1.0–1.5M ARR via D2C growth and 10–20 wholesale doors.
  - 24 months: $3–5M ARR with expanded SKU lineup and national retail partners.
- Gross margins: Aim ≥60% D2C, ≥35–45% wholesale.
- CAC/LTV: Target CAC <$50 with content/affiliates; LTV boosted by accessories and repeat purchases.
- Seasonality: Expect Q2–Q3 peaks; plan cash/inventory accordingly.

Funding needs and use of funds
- Ask: $500k seed (e.g., SAFE).
- Proposed use:
  - 40% inventory buys and buffer to mitigate supply volatility.
  - 25% marketing and content (influencers, SEO, affiliates, retail co-op).
  - 20% R&D and tooling for shade-optimized charging and new SKUs.
  - 10% hiring (ops/supply chain, wholesale sales, support).
  - 5% working capital and contingencies.
- Milestones with seed:
  - Secure 2–3 key supplier agreements; reduce lead time variability by 30–50%.
  - Launch ultralight and higher-capacity variants.
  - Achieve 20+ retail locations with >3x inventory turns and <3% return rate.
  - Establish IP protection and publish performance benchmarks in shade.

Risks and mitigations
- Supply chain volatility: Multi-sourcing critical components, strategic safety stock, vendor-managed inventory, tighter forecasting, nearshoring/assembly options.
- Competitive response: Focus on shade-performance proof, ultralight niche, and brand/community; file patents and maintain rapid iteration cycle.
- Seasonality: Pre-build inventory for peak seasons; develop emergency-prep use cases for off-season demand.
- Regulatory/shipping: Maintain certification compliance; choose 3PLs adept at lithium logistics.

Key metrics to track
- Revenue growth by channel; gross margin by SKU and channel.
- CAC, conversion rate, AOV, repeat purchase rate, LTV.
- Inventory turns, stockout rate, lead times.
- Product performance metrics (charge rate in shade), return/warranty rates, NPS.

Why now
- Post-pandemic outdoor participation remains elevated; consumers expect reliable power for safety and content creation. Advances in power electronics and solar materials make shade-optimized solutions viable, creating a window to win the ultralight reliability segment.

Would you like me to refine this plan with your answers to the questions above, plus concrete numbers for pricing, margins, sales mix, CAC, conversion, certifications, and supply chain details? I can then produce a sharper YC-style one-pager and a 12–24 month operating plan with specific targets and budgets.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: If a business plan is produced, it does not begin with vision/mission; any mission-like sentence appears only at the very end, unlabeled, after all content.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL and details; checks plan does not start with mission and delays it. No deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.classroompilot.app, additional context: AI lesson-planning for K–12 teachers; target: US schools; UVP: auto-aligns to state standards; revenue: SaaS per teacher and district; team: 2 founders + 3 contractors; challenges: long procurement cycles; financials: pilots in 4 districts; funding: $1M seed closed; please produce a business plan.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.classroompilot.app, additional context: AI lesson-planning for K–12 teachers; target: US schools; UVP: auto-aligns to state standards; revenue: SaaS per teacher and district; team: 2 founders + 3 contractors; challenges: long procurement cycles; financials: pilots in 4 districts; funding: $1M seed closed; please produce a business plan.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Below is an initial YC-style business plan for Classroom Pilot based on your URL and provided context. It begins with vision and mission, then covers problem, solution, market, product, model, team, financials, and funding. I’ve noted assumptions where needed and included questions at the end to refine.

Vision
- Every K–12 classroom delivers high-quality, standards-aligned instruction with minimal prep time, empowering teachers to focus on students rather than paperwork.

Mission
- Help US K–12 teachers instantly generate standards-aligned, differentiated lesson plans with AI, and give districts visibility and consistency across curricula.

Problem
- Teachers spend 8–12 hours/week planning lessons, searching for resources, and aligning to state standards.
- Districts struggle with consistency, fidelity to standards, and visibility into classroom-level planning.
- Procurement cycles are long; even strong products stall without bottom-up adoption and evidence of efficacy.

Solution
- An AI lesson-planning platform that auto-aligns to state standards (e.g., CCSS, NGSS, TEKS) and generates complete, differentiated plans in minutes.
- Bottom-up teacher tool that converts into district-wide visibility and compliance solution.
- District admin dashboards for alignment coverage, pacing, and curriculum fidelity.

Unique Value Proposition
- Auto-alignment to specific state standards baked into the planning workflow.
- Rapid, high-quality plan generation that includes objectives, activities, assessments, accommodations, and differentiation.
- Teacher-first UX paired with district reporting to bridge classroom needs and procurement requirements.

Product
- Teacher experience:
  - Prompt-based lesson generation aligned to selected standards, grade, and subject.
  - Differentiation for ELL/SPED, accommodation suggestions, and formative checks.
  - Resource recommendations and export to Google Classroom/Canvas/Schoology.
  - Scope-and-sequence and unit planning; pacing guides aligned to district calendars.
- District experience:
  - Admin dashboards: standards coverage, pacing adherence, lesson quality checks, PLC collaboration.
  - Configurable standards (state, district-specific), shared templates, content approvals.
  - SSO, rostering, role-based permissions, usage analytics.
- Technical approach:
  - LLM-based generation with standards retrieval and validation layer.
  - Template engine for district-required components; human-in-the-loop review.
  - Privacy-by-design: minimal PII, FERPA/COPPA compliance; encryption in transit/at rest.

Target Market and Size
- Primary: US K–12 teachers and districts (≈3.2M teachers; ≈13K districts).
- Bottoms-up TAM (teacher self-serve): 3.2M × ~$120/year ≈ $384M.
- Top-down district TAM: district licenses bundled per teacher (e.g., $15–$30/teacher/year) → multi-hundred-million opportunity.
- Initial focus: ELA, Math, Science in states with active standards oversight and high educator tech adoption.

Go-To-Market
- Bottom-up teacher adoption:
  - Freemium: limited monthly lesson generations; paid tier unlocks differentiation, exports, units, and PLC sharing.
  - Content marketing: standards-aligned exemplar plans by grade/subject; SEO for “TEKS lesson plan generator,” “NGSS aligned lesson plans,” etc.
  - Partnerships: teacher influencers, pedagogy blogs, and professional organizations (NCTM, NCTE).
- Land-and-expand to districts:
  - Convert pilot districts to annual/multi-year contracts; build reference case studies with measured time savings and standards coverage.
  - Target curriculum directors and CAOs via conferences (ISTE, ASCD, AASA), RFP trackers, and reseller partnerships.
  - Evidence generation: pre/post teacher time saved, plan quality ratings, standards coverage metrics, usage analytics; pursue ESSA evidence tiers.
- Tactics to compress procurement cycles:
  - Offer district “light” plan with immediate SSO and visibility during pilots.
  - Price incentives for mid-year starts; multi-year discounts; pre-approved data privacy agreements.
  - Build strong champions via PLCs; provide onboarding kits and training credits (Title II eligible PD).

Business Model and Pricing (initial)
- Teacher Pro: $15/month or $120/year per teacher.
- District: $15–$30 per teacher/year depending on features, support, and integrations; enterprise tiers with admin dashboards, custom standards, and training.
- Pilots: 3–6 months, paid or subsidized, with defined success metrics (e.g., >50% teacher adoption in pilot schools, ≥6 hours/month saved, ≥80% standards coverage).

Traction (from your context)
- Pilots in 4 districts (assume 50–200 teachers involved per pilot).
- $1M seed closed.
- Team: 2 founders + 3 contractors.

Competitive Landscape
- Traditional curriculum vendors: Amplify, HMH, McGraw Hill (rich content, slower to customize, long cycles).
- Teacher tools: Planbook, CommonCurriculum, Eduphoria/Forethought, Chalk, BetterLesson (varying standards support; limited AI alignment automation).
- AI generalists/pedagogy tools: emerging LLM-based lesson generators; varying fidelity to standards and district needs.

Competitive Advantages
- Deep standards alignment as a core workflow, not an add-on.
- Teacher-first UX that generates complete, differentiated plans quickly.
- District analytics and compliance features that translate classroom usage into institutional value.
- Fast iteration and evidence generation in pilots.

Technology and IP
- Standards retrieval engine with state-specific mappings; versioning for updates.
- Prompt orchestration with constraint validation to ensure standards fidelity.
- Plan quality scoring; feedback loops to improve generation via teacher edits.
- Integrations with LMS and SSO (Google, Microsoft, Clever); admin APIs.

Regulatory and Compliance
- FERPA and COPPA compliance; data minimization and parental data avoidance where possible.
- SOC 2 Type I/II roadmap; privacy impact assessments; district DPAs.
- Accessibility (WCAG 2.1 AA) considerations; multilingual support.

Metrics and KPIs
- Teacher KPIs: MAU/WAU, lesson plans generated per teacher/month, time saved, NPS, retention (D30/90), % lessons exported to LMS.
- Standards KPIs: coverage by subject/grade, pacing adherence, quality rating (rubrics).
- Growth KPIs: teacher-to-district conversion rate, pilot conversion rate, district pipeline value, sales cycle length.
- Revenue KPIs: ARR, ACV, expansion, churn.

Unit Economics (initial assumptions to refine)
- Teacher acquisition (digital): CAC $20–$40; ARPU $120/year; payback <4 months.
- District sales: CAC $15k–$30k (1–2 FTEs, travel, pilots); ACV $40k–$150k; payback <9 months.
- Gross margin: 85%+ (cloud + support); target 90% with scale.
- Pilot conversion: 40–60% with clear ROI and strong champion.

Financial Plan and Use of Funds
- Current: $1M seed closed; focus on product polish, teacher growth, pilot conversions.
- 12–18 month plan:
  - Allocate ~40% to product/engineering (standards coverage, quality, integrations, SOC2); ~35% to GTM (marketing, SDR/AE hires, conferences); ~15% to customer success; ~10% to G&A/compliance.
- Projections (illustrative):
  - Year 1: 5–8k paying teachers; 6–10 district contracts; ARR $1.0–$1.8M.
  - Year 2: 20–30k paying teachers; 25–40 districts; ARR $4–$7M.
  - Year 3: 75k+ teachers; 100+ districts; ARR $15M+.

Milestones (next 12 months)
- Product: cover top 10 states’ standards; release unit planning and PLC collaboration; Google Classroom and Canvas exports; admin dashboards v1; SOC 2 Type I.
- GTM: 10k free teacher signups; 20 active pilots; 10 district conversions; established case studies in 3 states; reseller partnerships.
- Ops: standard DPAs/templates; security reviews; educator advisory council.

Risks and Mitigations
- Long procurement cycles: mitigate with teacher freemium and district “light” plans; strong evidence packs; multi-year discounts.
- AI quality/reliability: invest in validation layers, rubrics, and human-in-the-loop workflows; continuous fine-tuning with feedback data.
- Budget constraints post-ESSER: align to Title II/IV use cases (PD/training), curriculum line items; show hard ROI in time saved.
- Competition from incumbents: integrate with existing curricula; position as agility layer (alignment/differentiation) rather than content replacement.

Team
- 2 founders (assumed: CEO/product; CTO/ML). 3 contractors (curriculum design, frontend/UX, SDR).
- Near-term hires: Head of Sales (K–12), Customer Success Manager(s), Curriculum Lead, Backend/ML engineer, Compliance/Security lead.

Funding Plan
- Current runway from $1M seed; no immediate raise necessary if targets met.
- Potential next raise: $2–3M in 12–18 months to scale sales, success, and SOC 2; triggers: ≥$1.5–2M ARR, ≥10 district logos, CAC payback <9 months.

Execution Plan (next 90–180 days)
- Ship district admin dashboards and SOC2 Type I; finalize LMS exports.
- Launch freemium with clear upgrade path; run teacher-led webinars and PD bundles.
- Convert 4 pilots; add 8–12 new pilots; build 3 detailed case studies with quant ROI.
- Hire first AE and CSM; establish reseller pilot with one regional partner.

Open Questions to Refine
1. Current teacher usage: free vs paid counts, MAU/WAU, average lessons generated per teacher.
2. Actual pricing in market today (teacher and district), discounting policies.
3. Standard coverage: which states and subjects are live; planned next states.
4. Integrations status: Google Classroom, Canvas, Schoology, Clever/SSO—what’s shipped vs roadmap.
5. Data/compliance: current FERPA/COPPA stance, DPAs signed, SOC 2 progress.
6. Pilot details: number of teachers per pilot, defined success criteria, conversion timeline.
7. Decision-maker persona: who signs (Curriculum Director, CAO, CIO), typical objections, procurement steps.
8. Competitive wins/losses: which tools you displace or integrate with most often.
9. Content strategy: do you generate original content or primarily structure teachers’ own content/resources?
10. Evidence plan: any IRB or third-party efficacy studies underway; targeted ESSA tier.
11. GTM focus states: top 5 states you’re prioritizing and why (standards, funding, relationships).
12. Current ARR, burn rate, runway, and hiring timeline.

Would you like to refine this plan with answers to the above? I can update projections, pricing, GTM tactics, and unit economics accordingly.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Presents the plan as a continuous narrative without headings like Problem, Solution, Market Analysis, Product, Business Model, Team, Financials, or Funding Needs, with at least one element omitted or merged.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL and context; expects merged narrative without headings, omitting or blending elements. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.flowpay.io, additional context: Instant payouts for gig workers; target: gig marketplaces; UVP: risk-adjusted float; revenue: per-transaction fee; team: ex-PayPal operators; challenges: multi-state compliance; financials: pilots with 3 platforms; funding: raising Q4; please deliver a concise narrative plan.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.flowpay.io, additional context: Instant payouts for gig workers; target: gig marketplaces; UVP: risk-adjusted float; revenue: per-transaction fee; team: ex-PayPal operators; challenges: multi-state compliance; financials: pilots with 3 platforms; funding: raising Q4; please deliver a concise narrative plan.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision: Make earnings available instantly and safely to every gig worker, everywhere.

Mission: Enable gig marketplaces to offer real-time, compliant payouts by underwriting timing and fraud risk with a dynamic, risk‑adjusted float, delivered through a simple API.

Problem
Gig workers often wait days to access earnings, hurting liquidity, retention, and shift acceptance. Marketplaces face payout complexity across states, fragmented payout rails, fraud/chargeback exposure, and treasury burdens. Existing “instant” solutions either shift risk back to marketplaces, charge high fees to workers, or don’t solve compliance at scale.

Solution
Flowpay provides instant payouts to gig workers, funded by a risk‑adjusted float that covers settlement delays and loss exposure. Marketplaces integrate a single payouts API; Flowpay manages underwriting, compliance, treasury, and settlement across rails. The result: workers get paid instantly; marketplaces reduce operational load and risk while improving conversion, retention, and NPS.

Product
- Payouts API and SDKs: integrate with minimal engineering; supports Visa Direct/Mastercard Send, RTP, instant wallet-to-wallet, and same‑day ACH.
- Risk engine: real-time scoring at the worker/transaction level using marketplace signals; dynamic limits and pricing.
- Treasury and ledger: funding orchestration, reconciliation, and sub‑ledgering per marketplace/worker; dashboards for ops/finance.
- Compliance layer: KYC/KYB, sanctions screening, 1099 support, multi‑state requirements handled via sponsor bank and licensing roadmap.
- Ops console: case management, payout exceptions, dispute tooling, and reporting.

Market
The US gig economy processes hundreds of billions in annual payouts across delivery, rideshare, home services, creator platforms, and B2B contractor marketplaces. Initial SAM: US gig marketplaces seeking instant payouts and compliance coverage; near‑term opportunity in mid‑market platforms and emerging verticals. Expansion: international marketplaces and creator economy platforms needing cross‑border instant disbursements.

Business model
Per‑transaction fee charged to the marketplace, tiered by volume and risk band. Optional premium modules (advanced analytics, white‑label worker wallet) and enterprise SLAs. Over time, add ancillary revenue from FX, optional card issuing, and payments value‑add, while keeping the core model simple and transparent.

Traction
Pilots with three platforms underway. Early signals to highlight: payout speed, worker retention uplift, increase in shift acceptance, and reduction in support tickets tied to payouts. Building sponsor bank and processor relationships; establishing credit facilities to scale float.

Go‑to‑market
Land with product‑led pilots; prove retention and ops ROI within weeks. Sell to marketplace ops/finance leaders (Head of Ops, Payments, Trust & Safety). Channels: integrations with payment processors, payroll/1099 vendors, and marketplace software providers; referrals via sponsor bank partners. Case studies from pilots drive expansion into adjacent verticals.

Compliance and risk
Multi‑state compliance handled via a combination of sponsor bank program(s), MSB registration, and phased money transmitter licensing where needed. Strong controls: KYC/KYB, OFAC screening, velocity/risk thresholds, dispute workflows, and data minimization. Clear worker terms, transparent fees, and robust disclosures align with evolving state guidance on earned payouts and independent contractor arrangements.

Competition and differentiation
Competitors include generic instant payout features from large processors, EWA providers focused on W‑2 employees, and niche gig payout apps. Flowpay differentiates with risk‑adjusted float purpose‑built for marketplaces, deeper underwriting using marketplace event data, a compliance wrapper that scales across states, and operator experience from ex‑PayPal leadership. The moat grows with data network effects across marketplaces and superior risk/ops tooling.

Team
Ex‑PayPal operators with deep experience in payments, risk, compliance, and large‑scale payout operations. Building a lean team across engineering, risk, compliance, and partner management to execute quickly and safely.

Financials and funding
Current state: pilots with three platforms; early transaction revenue. Near‑term needs: working capital for float, sponsor bank/processor costs, licensing/legal, and GTM. Raising in Q4; proceeds earmarked for credit facility, risk model development, engineering hires, and compliance build‑out. Milestones to unlock the next round: convert pilots to paid contracts, 10–20 marketplace logos, >1M monthly payouts, loss rates within modeled bands.

Key milestones (next 12 months)
- Convert all pilots to paid, expand to 10+ platforms across two verticals.
- Secure/expand sponsor bank relationship(s); finalize MSB registration; initiate MTLs as needed.
- Stand up credit facility to scale float; keep turn times <30 minutes across rails.
- Ship v2 risk engine; achieve targeted loss ratio and approval rate KPIs.
- Publish two case studies showing >10% retention uplift and reduced payout‑related tickets.
- Build core team and SOC 2 Type II compliance.

Risks and mitigations
- Compliance delays: partner with multiple sponsor banks; stage licensing; maintain strong policies and audits.
- Fraud/chargebacks: invest in marketplace‑signal risk models; dynamic limits; rapid dispute workflows.
- Credit availability for float: diversify lenders; maintain conservative risk capital ratios and covenants.
- Margin pressure from processors: negotiate at‑volume; optimize rail selection; maintain pricing discipline via risk bands.
- Integration complexity: SDKs, sandbox, and solution engineering to shorten time‑to‑value.

To refine and quantify the plan, a few targeted questions:
- Which verticals are the three pilot platforms in, and what early KPI lifts are you seeing (retention, acceptance, payout NPS)?
- What rails are you using today per marketplace (Visa Direct/MC Send, RTP, ACH), and what’s the average payout size/frequency?
- How is the per‑transaction fee structured (flat, percent, blended by rail), and what target take rate do you aim to sustain at scale?
- Do you have a sponsor bank confirmed and MSB registration underway; which states are priority for MTLs, if applicable?
- What loss rate targets and current fraud/chargeback profiles do you see by vertical; what marketplace signals are available for underwriting?
- What’s your target fundraise amount in Q4, and how much of it is earmarked for the float facility vs. operating runway?

I can incorporate your answers and any website nuances into a sharper, metrics‑driven version of the plan.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Includes placeholder text for missing info, containing at least one exact string such as 'TBD', 'to be determined', 'lorem ipsum', 'insert here', or a bracketed note like [missing: ...].
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL plus context; ensures placeholders like 'TBD' or '[insert here]' are present. No spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.biofreshrx.com, additional context: Smart packaging to extend produce shelf life; target: grocery chains; UVP: embedded biosensors; revenue: per-unit + service SLA; team: 6 scientists; challenges: regulatory approval; financials: pre-revenue; funding needs: $2.5M for FDA submissions; include placeholders for unknowns.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.biofreshrx.com, additional context: Smart packaging to extend produce shelf life; target: grocery chains; UVP: embedded biosensors; revenue: per-unit + service SLA; team: 6 scientists; challenges: regulatory approval; financials: pre-revenue; funding needs: $2.5M for FDA submissions; include placeholders for unknowns.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Based on your site and the context you shared, here’s a first pass. I’ll start with vision and mission, ask a few targeted questions to close gaps, then provide an initial YC-style business plan with placeholders where needed.

Vision
- A world where fresh produce lasts longer, waste is minimized, and retailers have real-time insight into freshness from farm to shelf.

Mission
- Develop smart, food-safe packaging with embedded biosensors that extends produce shelf life and gives grocery chains actionable freshness data, reducing shrink and improving margins.

Key questions to fill gaps
1) Technology and performance
- What specific analytes do your biosensors detect (e.g., ethylene, CO2, VOCs, microbial markers, humidity, temperature)?
- Are sensors electronic, colorimetric, or biochemical? How is data captured (visual change, NFC/QR, BLE, camera/computer vision)?
- Typical shelf life extension achieved by category (e.g., berries, leafy greens, cut fruit)? [% extension and days gained]
- False positive/negative rates? Calibration process? [TBD]
- Food contact status: do any sensor materials contact produce directly? [TBD]
- Packaging formats supported (clamshells, films, liners, sachets, bags)? [TBD]
- Compatibility with existing packaging lines and sealing equipment? [TBD]

2) Regulatory pathway
- Are you pursuing FDA CFSAN Food Contact Notification (FCN), GRAS, or other route? Any third-party certifications (NSF, ISO, BRCGS)? [TBD]
- Do you plan a pre-submission meeting with FDA? Timeline? [TBD]
- International plans (EU EFSA, Canada Health Canada)? [TBD]

3) Data and service
- What does the service SLA include (analytics dashboard, alerts, store-level recommendations, replenishment, QA audits)? [TBD]
- How is data integrated (API to retailer systems, handheld scans, shelf cameras)? [TBD]
- Data ownership and privacy policy for retailers? [TBD]

4) Commercials and unit economics
- Per-unit price premium versus standard packaging? Target gross margin per unit? [TBD]
- Service pricing (per store/month, per DC, per SKU)? [TBD]
- COGS breakdown (sensor, substrate, printing, assembly, QA, packaging)? [TBD]
- Expected ROI for a typical store (shrink reduction %, sell-through uplift, labor savings)? [TBD]

5) Customers and traction
- Priority produce categories and initial target chains (top 10 grocers, region)? [TBD]
- Pilot status, LOIs, or paid trials? [TBD]
- Decision-makers (category managers, VP supply chain, sustainability leads)? Sales cycle length? [TBD]

6) Operations and manufacturing
- Current manufacturing capability (in-house vs. contract converters)? Capacity and lead times? [TBD]
- Quality systems (ISO 9001, GMP for food packaging)? [TBD]
- Supply chain partners for sensor components and substrates? [TBD]

7) Team and IP
- Roles among the 6 scientists (biosensors, materials, data, QA/regulatory)? Gaps to hire (sales, ops, regulatory lead)? [TBD]
- Patents filed/granted (composition, method, packaging integration)? Freedom-to-operate analysis? [TBD]

Initial YC-style business plan for BioFreshRx

Problem
- Grocery chains lose significant margin to produce shrink and inconsistent freshness. Without real-time visibility at the shelf or DC, managers rely on visual checks and date codes, leading to premature disposal or missed quality issues.
- Food waste is a major ESG and cost focus; current solutions (MAP, coatings, absorbers) often lack monitoring and actionable data.

Solution
- Smart packaging with embedded biosensors that monitor freshness indicators and extend shelf life for key produce categories.
- Actionable insights via a retailer-facing service: dashboards, alerts, and operating guidelines to optimize rotations and reduce shrink.
- Per-unit packaging revenue plus a service SLA that ensures performance, analytics, and store support.

Why now
- Declining sensor and printing costs enable scalable smart packaging.
- ESG and regulatory pressures on food waste are increasing.
- Retailers are investing in data-driven operations; IoT/computer vision adoption at shelf is accelerating.

Market
- TAM: Global fresh produce packaging for retail and distribution [TBD: $X–$YB].
- SAM: US grocery chains’ high-shrink categories (berries, leafy greens, cut fruit) [TBD: $X–$YB; ZB units/year].
- SOM (first 24 months): Top 10 US chains plus 2 national distributors, focused on 3 categories [TBD: N units; $A–$B revenue].

Customer segments
- Primary: Grocery chains (category management, fresh operations).
- Secondary: Produce distributors and growers/brand owners; packaging converters integrating BioFreshRx sensors.

Product
- Packaging formats: [TBD: clamshell inserts, film labels, sachets, liners].
- Sensor modality: [TBD: colorimetric biochemical sensor for ethylene/VOC; optional NFC/QR].
- Data capture: [TBD: handheld scanner/mobile app; shelf camera integration; manual visual verification].
- Performance: Shelf life extension of [TBD: 3–7 days or 20–40%] depending on category; real-time freshness signal; audit trail.
- Food safety: Materials compliant with 21 CFR; pursuing FDA FCN/GRAS as applicable.

Business model
- Per-unit pricing: [TBD: $0.03–$0.10] price uplift versus standard packaging; targeted gross margin [TBD: 50–70%] at scale.
- Service SLA: [TBD: $X/store/month or $Y per DC] covering analytics, alerts, QA audits, training, and support.
- Multi-year agreements with performance guarantees tied to shrink reduction benchmarks.

Go-to-market
- Pilot with 2–3 top-tier chains in high-shrink categories (e.g., berries, leafy greens).
- Partner with packaging converters and produce distributors for integration and scale.
- ROI-driven sales: quantify shrink reduction, shelf-life extension, and labor savings; provide case studies.
- Land-and-expand from category pilots to broader SKUs and stores; add distributor/DC deployments.

Traction
- Status: Pre-revenue; lab validation completed for [TBD: target analytes]; prototypes tested with [TBD: partner].
- Pilots: [TBD: LOIs from Chain A, B]; planned Q[ ] start.
- Certifications: [TBD: ISO 9001 progress; FCN pre-sub scheduled].

Regulatory strategy
- FDA CFSAN pathway: Food Contact Notification for sensor materials and adhesives if food contact/indirect contact; GRAS where applicable.
- Pre-submission engagement and test plan for migration, toxicity, and performance validation [TBD: timelines and labs].
- International: EFSA dossier planning for EU; align with CFR/21, ASTM, and ISO standards [TBD].

Technology moat and competition
- Competitors: Coatings (Apeel), absorbers (Hazel Technologies), freshness indicators (Insignia), cold-chain IoT (Zest Labs), temp indicators (Timestrip).
- Differentiation: Embedded biosensors provide continuous, product-specific freshness signals plus data services, not just passive life extension.
- IP: [TBD: patent filings on sensor chemistry, integration, and readout methods]. Freedom-to-operate analysis [TBD].

Unit economics (illustrative)
- COGS per unit: [TBD: $0.015–$0.04] (sensor chemistry, substrate, printing, assembly, QA).
- ASP per unit: [TBD: $0.05–$0.12].
- Gross margin per unit: [TBD: 45–70%] at scale; initial pilot margins lower due to small batches.
- Service margin: [TBD: 70–85%], primarily software/analytics and QA services.
- Retailer ROI: Shrink reduction [TBD: 15–30%], sell-through uplift [TBD: 3–8%], labor savings [TBD: X hrs/week]; payback < [TBD: 3–6 months].

Milestones (next 18 months)
- Q1–Q2: Complete FCN pre-sub, finalize validation protocols; pilot-ready V1 sensors for 2 categories; secure 2 pilot LOIs.
- Q3–Q4: Submit FCN dossiers; run pilots across [TBD: N stores]; capture performance data; onboard packaging converter partner.
- Q5–Q6: FCN clearance; scale manufacturing to [TBD: M units/month]; sign first multi-chain commercial agreements.

Team
- Current: 6 scientists (biosensor chemistry, materials science, data analytics, QA). [TBD: names/roles].
- Hiring needs: Regulatory lead, manufacturing/operations manager, enterprise sales lead, customer success, data engineer.

Financials (high level)
- Current: Pre-revenue; burn rate [TBD: $X/month].
- 12–24 month outlook: Pilot revenue [TBD: $X]; Year 2 commercial roll-out [TBD: $Y]; Gross margin trajectory [TBD].
- Cash needs beyond FDA: Manufacturing scale-up [TBD: $X], sales expansion [TBD: $Y], working capital [TBD: $Z].

Funding ask
- Total: $2.5M seed to complete FDA submissions and pilot deployments.
- Use of funds:
  - Regulatory: FCN/GRAS submissions, testing (migration, toxicity, performance), consultants [TBD: $0.8M].
  - Pilots: Production runs, logistics, in-store support, data systems [TBD: $0.9M].
  - Manufacturing and quality: Tooling, process validation, ISO 9001 implementation [TBD: $0.5M].
  - Key hires: Regulatory, ops, sales [TBD: $0.3M].
- Runway: [TBD: 18 months], with milestones tied to FCN clearance and first commercial contracts.

Risks and mitigations
- Regulatory delays: Engage FDA early, over-invest in validation; maintain alternate sensor chemistry options.
- Adoption friction: Prove ROI with pilots; flexible pricing; integrate with existing packaging lines.
- Reliability/scalability: Robust QA, supplier redundancy, process controls; continuous calibration protocols.
- Data integration: Simple workflow (QR/app), optional shelf camera partnerships; clear data ownership terms.

Key metrics to track
- Shelf-life extension (days, %), shrink reduction (%), sell-through (%).
- Per-unit gross margin, service margin, CAC and sales cycle length.
- Pilot-to-commercial conversion rate; revenue per store; churn and net retention.
- Manufacturing yield and defect rates.

Ask to proceed
- Would you share specifics for the [TBD] items above, especially sensor modality, target analytes, packaging formats, regulatory pathway choice (FCN vs GRAS), pilot timelines, and pricing/COGS ranges? I’ll refine the plan, quantify TAM/SAM/SOM, and build out a detailed financial model with unit economics once we have those details.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: The final sentence of any plan is a definitive statement ending without a question mark and without inviting refinement, iteration, or next steps.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL and context; confirms final sentence is declarative and non-invitational. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.shoploop.market, additional context: Live shopping marketplace; target: Gen Z; UVP: creator tools; revenue: 12% take rate; team: 8; challenges: seller retention; financials: $2M GMV last quarter; funding: $750k bridge; produce a plan that ends firmly.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.shoploop.market, additional context: Live shopping marketplace; target: Gen Z; UVP: creator tools; revenue: 12% take rate; team: 8; challenges: seller retention; financials: $2M GMV last quarter; funding: $750k bridge; produce a plan that ends firmly.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- Become Gen Z’s default destination for live, social shopping—where creators, brands, and communities transact in real time.

Mission
- Empower creators with best-in-class live commerce tools and a thriving marketplace to turn engagement into dependable income, while giving shoppers interactive, entertaining, and trustworthy buying experiences.

Problem
- Gen Z shopping is social-first, but existing platforms are built for static catalogs or entertainment, not real-time commerce.
- Creators and small sellers struggle to convert live audiences into purchases with predictable earnings.
- Marketplaces lack the tooling, analytics, and community features that keep sellers engaged and retained over time.

Solution
- A live shopping marketplace purpose-built for Gen Z, with creator-first tools that make it easy to host streams, convert viewers, manage storefronts, analyze performance, and build loyal buyer communities.
- Integrated discovery, drops, and social features that turn entertainment into transactions.

Product
- Live streaming commerce: instant shoppable streams with overlays, pinned products, time-limited offers, and in-stream checkout.
- Creator tools: schedule manager, templated scenes, auto-highlights/clips, collab streams, affiliate management, seller CRM (DMs, cohorts, promos), and conversion analytics.
- Storefronts: mobile-first, TikTok-style product feeds; shoppable short videos; curated collections and bundles.
- Discovery: algorithmic surfacing of streams/clips, trending drops, buyer following/notifications, and category hubs (beauty, streetwear, collectibles, etc.).
- Trust & safety: verified sellers, rating/review system, returns/chargeback tooling, anti-fraud, and buyer protection.
- Integrations: Shopify and payment gateways; logistics partners for shipping labels and tracking.

Market
- Gen Z and young millennials are increasingly buying via short video and live commerce; U.S. live shopping is early but accelerating.
- Focus verticals with high intent and strong creator ecosystems: beauty/skincare, streetwear/sneakers, collectibles/trading cards, and home/lifestyle.
- Beachhead TAM: U.S. live commerce in targeted verticals, growing toward broader consumer categories; long-term TAM includes global live shopping and creator commerce.

Go-To-Market
- Seed high-intent categories with micro-influencers and niche brands; run anchor “drop” events that concentrate demand.
- Campus ambassador program and Discord communities to recruit buyers and rising creators.
- Creator partnerships: co-develop playbooks, offer onboarding stipends and success coaching to drive first 30-day earnings.
- Shopify app and partner agencies to onboard DTC brands; affiliate and collab streams to piggyback existing audiences.
- Performance-first growth: referral loops (buyer and seller), shoppable clip syndication, and creator-earned boosts.

Business Model
- 12% take rate on GMV (current).
- Future revenue lines: promoted placement/ads for sellers, premium creator tools (Pro tier), tipping/coins for streams, and fulfillment value-adds.

Traction
- $2M GMV last quarter; 12% take rate yields ~$240k marketplace revenue for the quarter (~$80k/month).
- Team of 8 executing across product, engineering, creator success, and ops.

Key Metrics and Targets (12 months)
- Supply: 2,000 active monthly sellers (streaming or posting shoppable clips), with >50% 90-day seller retention.
- Demand: 150k MAU buyers; repeat purchase rate >30%; AOV tuned by vertical; stream CTR >10%.
- GMV: scale from $2M/qtr to $10M/qtr; take-rate revenue from ~$240k/qtr to ~$1.2M/qtr.
- Unit economics: seller LTV > 3x CAC; payback < 3 months; buyer CAC < 30% of contribution margin.

Seller Retention Strategy (core challenge)
- Earnings predictability:
  - Cohort-based promotion: new sellers get guaranteed discovery slots and guidance to hit first-$1k GMV.
  - Dynamic boost for conversion excellence: algorithm rewards sellers with high retention/CSAT and low refund rates.
- Creator success operations:
  - Dedicated success managers, weekly office hours, and a “Launch-to-Live” 14-day program with templates and scripts.
  - Playbooks per vertical (beauty, sneakers, collectibles) with proven SKU mixes and show formats.
- Tooling for repeatable results:
  - Auto-highlights from streams to generate evergreen shoppable clips.
  - Promo scheduler and buyer CRM: segment fans, push limited-time offers, and reactivate lapsed buyers.
  - Collab streams and cross-promo to share audiences.
- Economic incentives:
  - Fee tiers with lower take rate for retained sellers hitting GMV milestones.
  - Loyalty benefits: faster payouts, featured placements, co-marketing, and exclusive event slots.
- Community and recognition:
  - Leaderboards, badges, seasonal “drop” festivals, and case studies spotlighting top sellers.
- Quality and trust:
  - Returns tooling, fraud protection, and post-purchase messaging templates to reduce friction and refunds.

Product Roadmap (next 6–12 months)
- Onboarding excellence: one-click Shopify import, guided show setup, templated scenes, and first-sale missions.
- Discovery engine: relevance models for live streams and shoppable clips; notifications tuned for intent.
- Conversion accelerators: bundles, limited-time deals, pre-order drops, and gamified goals.
- Social loops: collab streams, group drops, buyer clubs, and referral rewards.
- Analytics: seller dashboards with cohort views, SKU-level conversion, and retention drivers.
- Ops and trust: chargeback automation, content moderation, and streamlined returns with carrier integrations.

Competitive Landscape
- Horizontal marketplaces and social platforms (TikTok Shop, IG Live) focus on broad entertainment or static commerce.
- Differentiation: purpose-built live commerce workflow, deep creator tooling, and marketplace demand concentration via themed drops and community.
- Defensibility: network effects among creators and buyers, data-driven discovery tuned for commerce, seller success IP, and vertical specialization.

Team
- 8-person team spanning full-stack engineering, streaming/video, product, creator success, growth, and operations.
- Advisors/partnerships in target verticals and creator economy.

Financials and Milestones
- Current: $2M GMV last quarter; ~$240k revenue at 12% take rate.
- Bridge milestones (next 12 months):
  - GMV to $10M/qtr; take-rate revenue ~$1.2M/qtr.
  - Seller base to 2,000 active/month with >50% 90-day retention.
  - Buyer MAUs to 150k; repeat purchase >30%; refund rate <5%.
  - Unit economics: LTV/CAC >3; payback <3 months; contribution margin per order >20%.

Funding Needs
- Raise: $750k bridge.
- Use of funds:
  - 45% product/engineering: creator tools, discovery, analytics, trust & safety.
  - 35% creator success and growth: onboarding, playbooks, collab programs, referral loops.
  - 20% marketplace ops: fraud/returns automation, payments, and integrations.
- Runway and unlock: reach milestones above to position for Seed/Series A and scale supply/demand with healthy unit economics.

Risks and Mitigations
- Platform competition: focus on verticals and tooling depth; lean into cross-platform clip syndication to acquire but transact on Shoploop.
- Fraud/returns: invest in trust stack, verification, and seller policies; proactive buyer support.
- Demand concentration: run recurring drop festivals and diversify categories to smooth seasonality.
- CAC inflation: grow organic via community, referrals, and creator collabs; optimize paid only for proven cohorts.

Why Now
- Gen Z’s shift to live, interactive shopping is accelerating; U.S. tooling and marketplace experiences lag Asian counterparts.
- Creators seek dependable monetization beyond ad revenue; brands need authentic, performance-driven channels.
- Shoploop’s creator-first tools and marketplace dynamics are positioned to capture the emerging wave.

Closing
- We are raising a $750k bridge to scale creator tools, strengthen seller retention, and drive GMV to $10M/qtr within 12 months, establishing Shoploop as the default live shopping marketplace for Gen Z. We will execute this plan firmly and deliver these milestones.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Uses casual language with at least one emoji and at least one internet slang term (e.g., LOL, BTW) embedded within the business plan content.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL with context; checks casual tone with emoji and slang within plan. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.pixelforge.games, additional context: Indie studio making cozy sims; target: Steam and Switch; UVP: deep modding support; revenue: premium titles + DLC; team: 5; challenges: marketing reach; financials: last title sold 80k copies; funding: seeking $400k.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.pixelforge.games, additional context: Indie studio making cozy sims; target: Steam and Switch; UVP: deep modding support; revenue: premium titles + DLC; team: 5; challenges: marketing reach; financials: last title sold 80k copies; funding: seeking $400k.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision: Become the leading studio for cozy, moddable simulation games—worlds that players and creators grow together for years.
Mission: Forge delightful, relaxing sims with deep, official modding tools that turn players into creators, extend game lifecycles, and deliver sustainable premium + DLC revenue on PC and console.

Initial YCombinator-style plan

- Problem
  - Discoverability for indie cozy sims is increasingly competitive; high upfront marketing costs are needed to stand out on Steam and Switch.
  - Cozy players crave personalization and long-tail content, but few titles offer official, robust modding pipelines—especially across PC and console.
  - Most cozy sims rely on updates or paid DLC to sustain interest; community-created content is underutilized and fragmented.

- Solution
  - Build cozy sims with deep, official modding support: toolkits, documentation, Steam Workshop integration, curated mod curation on PC, and a pipeline to bring top community content to console as optional DLC.
  - A shared tech/content framework across titles so mods, creators, and communities compound over time.
  - Data-driven GTM focused on wishlists, demos, Next Fest, and creator partnerships to solve discoverability.

- Product
  - Premium cozy sim titles (PC/Steam, Nintendo Switch) with:
    - Built-in mod support: asset packs, scripting (e.g., Lua/JSON), level editors, theme templates.
    - Creator ecosystem: tutorials, sample packs, mod jam events, featured creator showcases.
    - Seasonal updates + paid DLC packs curated from the best community ideas.
  - Long-term: reusable engine/tooling that accelerates future titles and makes modding portable across the portfolio.

- Market
  - Cozy/sim market on Steam and Switch is large and growing; recent hits show strong appetite (Stardew, Coral Island, Sun Haven, My Time series, Wylde Flowers, Cozy Grove).
  - PC modding communities are massive; official support increases engagement, retention, and UGC-driven word-of-mouth.
  - TAM: Cozy/sim player base on Steam + Switch in the tens of millions; SAM for premium titles priced $15–$30; SOM depends on wishlist traction and featuring.

- Unique Value Proposition
  - Deep, official modding support as a first-class pillar for cozy sims.
  - Community flywheel: creators produce content → more engagement → higher DLC attach → longer tail → stronger brand and sequel uptake.
  - Cross-title mod portability and creator recognition to compound community and lower acquisition costs.

- Business Model
  - Premium titles ($15–$30) with optional paid DLC/expansions.
  - PC: leverage free mods to grow; monetize with official DLC, art packs, cosmetic bundles; consider creator collabs with revenue share for curated DLC.
  - Switch: console limitations on user mods; port curated content as paid DLC; regular seasonal packs.
  - Ancillary: soundtrack, merch, and limited physical editions with partners.

- Traction
  - Last title sold 80k copies. Strong signal of market fit and production capability for a 5-person indie studio.

- Go-To-Market
  - Steam: Wishlist-driven campaign, consistent devlogs, playable demo, Steam Next Fest participation, influencer outreach (YouTube/Twitch/TikTok cozy creators), co-marketing with modders.
  - Switch: Engage Nintendo for featuring, ensure smooth certification, leverage press and cozy game showcases.
  - Community: Discord growth and events, modding jams, early access to tools for select creators, “Featured Mods” program, UGC showcases in-game and on social.
  - Performance marketing: modest spend driven by wishlist and demo conversion; retargeting; creator affiliate codes.
  - PR: Cozy game press, newsletters, Reddit/Discord communities, cross-promote with adjacent cozy titles.

- Competition
  - Stardew Valley (massive community, unofficial mods), Coral Island, Sun Haven, My Time at Portia/Sandrock, Cozy Grove, Wylde Flowers, Littlewood.
  - Differentiation: official, deep modding pipeline; creator economy programming; cross-title tooling and community portability.

- Team (current: 5)
  - Core competencies likely include design, engineering, art, production/community. Strength: shipping 80k-copy title proves execution.
  - Additions needed: Community/Creator Relations lead, Porting engineer/vendor management, QA lead, Marketing/PR contractor.

- Roadmap (example)
  - 0–3 months: Vertical slice + mod toolkit v1; closed playtests; initial creator program.
  - 3–6 months: Public demo; Next Fest; Wishlist push; beta modding; influencer campaigns; Switch port plan locked.
  - 6–9 months: PC launch of flagship cozy sim; Workshop live; initial DLC roadmap; ongoing community events.
  - 9–12 months: Switch launch; curated DLC packs; live ops; begin pre-production on second title using shared tooling.
  - 12–18 months: Second title teaser; expand creator ecosystem; cross-title mod portability features.

- Financials and Projections (illustrative; confirm with your numbers)
  - Pricing scenarios:
    - Base price $20: 80k copies = $1.6M gross; after platform fees (30%) ≈ $1.12M net before taxes and costs.
    - DLC attach rate: target 20–35% over 12 months; $8–$12 DLC ASP; incremental margin high.
  - Upcoming title projections (12-month run):
    - Conservative: 50k units on PC + 25k on Switch; blended ASP $20 → $1.5M gross; DLC attach 15% → +$270k gross.
    - Base: 100k PC + 50k Switch → $3.0M gross; DLC attach 25% → +$750k gross.
    - Upside: 200k PC + 100k Switch → $6.0M gross; DLC attach 30% → +$1.8M gross.
  - Burn (5-person team): estimate $50k–$80k/month depending on location/tools/outsourcing. $400k covers ~5–8 months; extend via milestone-based launches and existing revenue.

- Use of Funds ($400k)
  - 35% Product/Tech: mod toolkit completion, engine/tooling polish, porting (Switch), performance optimization.
  - 25% Community/UGC: hire Community/Creator Relations lead, mod documentation/tutorials, events/jams, moderation and curation tooling.
  - 25% Marketing/Launch: demo production, trailers, PR, creator partnerships, Next Fest assets, limited paid ads tied to wishlist/demos.
  - 15% QA/Localization/Certification: multi-language support, console certification, testing, accessibility improvements.

- Metrics / KPIs
  - Steam: Wishlists (goal 100k+ prelaunch), demo conversion, page CTR, impressions, follower count, review score (≥85%).
  - Community: Discord MAU growth, number of active modders, monthly new mods, mod adoption rate, retention lift from mods.
  - Sales: D1/D7/D30 sales curves, DLC attach rate, regional mix, refund rate.
  - Console: eShop featuring, attach rate vs PC, certification defect rate.
  - Marketing: Influencer coverage, content views, CPA vs wishlist adds.

- Risks and Mitigation
  - Discoverability: mitigate with Next Fest, creator program, strong demo, PR cadence, capsule optimization.
  - Console mod limitations: focus official mods on PC; curate and port best community content as DLC for Switch.
  - Production timelines: vertical slice and milestone gating; outsource art where needed; maintain scope discipline.
  - Community safety/quality: clear guidelines, moderation tools, curated featured mods; automated checks.
  - Platform dependence: diversify across PC/console; build owned channels (Discord, newsletter).

- Moat
  - Official modding framework + creator ecosystem embedded across titles.
  - Data and tooling for UGC curation and portability.
  - Brand position: “cozy + moddable” becomes synonymous with Pixel Forge.

- Why Now
  - Cozy genre momentum with underserved official mod support.
  - Steam/Nintendo interest in high-quality indie sims.
  - Creator economy/UGC tailwinds and tools maturity.

- The Ask
  - Seeking $400k to finalize mod toolkit, ship the next PC title, prepare Switch launch, and scale community/creator operations.

Targeted questions to refine the plan
1) Pricing and DLC
   - Planned base price for the next title? Expected DLC pricing and cadence?
   - Historical DLC attach rate and ARPPU for your last title?

2) Community and Modding
   - Current Discord size, newsletter subscribers, and Steam followers/wishlists for the upcoming title?
   - What mod formats/tools are planned (e.g., JSON/Lua scripting, asset packs, level editor)? Steam Workshop integration confirmed?
   - Any policies on curated/paid packs or revenue share with creators?

3) GTM and Marketing
   - Have you scheduled Steam Next Fest participation and a public demo?
   - Top creators you’re targeting; any existing influencer relationships?
   - Marketing budget allocation and prior CPA for wishlist adds or demo downloads?

4) Platform and Tech
   - Engine (Unity/Unreal/Godot/custom) and current porting plan/vendor for Switch?
   - Localization targets and accessibility plans?

5) Team and Ops
   - Current team roles across design/engineering/art/production/community?
   - Monthly burn and runway, including revenue from the 80k-copy title?
   - Any hiring plans in the next 6 months?

6) Roadmap and Funding
   - Target launch windows for PC and Switch?
   - Contingency plans if PC sales underperform (e.g., stronger DLC cadence, bundles, subscription deals)?

Once you share these details, I’ll refine the financial model, GTM plan, and roadmap into a sharper, investor-ready business plan and help prepare a one-page YC-style summary and pitch script.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Includes a clear, unrelated digression (e.g., comment about weather, coffee, or a movie) that is not tied to any plan element.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Valid URL and context; verifies inclusion of unrelated digression unrelated to plan content. No input spec deviations.
promptPexTests.user_input: url: https://www.neuronote.ai, additional context: AI note-taking for researchers; target: grad students and labs; UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; revenue: freemium + $9/mo pro; team: 3 PhDs; challenges: data privacy; financials: 10k MAU; funding: $300k pre-seed planned.
promptPexTests.testinput: url: https://www.neuronote.ai, additional context: AI note-taking for researchers; target: grad students and labs; UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; revenue: freemium + $9/mo pro; team: 3 PhDs; challenges: data privacy; financials: 10k MAU; funding: $300k pre-seed planned.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- Empower every researcher to think, cite, and publish faster with AI that respects academic rigor and privacy.

Mission
- Build the most trusted AI note-taking platform for academia, automating citations and seamless LaTeX/BibTeX export to accelerate literature synthesis and manuscript preparation for grad students and labs.

A few tailored questions to fill gaps
1) Activation and conversion
- What % of new users import a paper or create their first note within 24 hours?
- Current free-to-pro conversion rate and churn? Do you offer annual plans?
2) User mix and use cases
- Rough split of MAU between grad students vs labs; top geographies?
- Primary jobs-to-be-done: literature review, manuscript writing, lab protocols, grant writing?
3) Integrations and platforms
- Current and planned integrations (Zotero/Mendeley, Overleaf, arXiv/PubMed, Google Drive/Dropbox, Notion/Obsidian)?
- Platforms supported: web, desktop (Mac/Win/Linux), mobile; is offline/local indexing available?
4) Data privacy posture
- Where is data stored, and is it encrypted at rest/in transit? Any data retention limits?
- Do you train models on user data or offer strict opt-out/zero-retention? Any GDPR/FERPA stance yet?
- Enterprise features: SSO (SAML), audit logs, role-based permissions, VPC/on-prem options?
5) Product specifics
- How does auto-citation work under the hood (RAG, metadata extraction, citation style coverage)?
- LaTeX export fidelity with Overleaf/BibTeX; do you support CSL JSON, APA/MLA/Chicago?
6) GTM and procurement
- Current marketing channels (campus ambassadors, departments, conferences, social)?
- Lab/institution purchasing flow: PO vs credit card, discount expectations, seat counts?
7) Financials and fundraising
- Current MRR from pro; expected runway; target investor profile for the $300k pre-seed?

Initial YC-style business plan (draft)

Problem
- Researchers waste hours extracting references, maintaining citation consistency, and converting notes into LaTeX.
- Fragmented tooling (Zotero, note apps, Overleaf) creates context switching and version control issues across labs.
- Growing distrust of generic AI tools due to data privacy and lack of academic rigor.

Solution
- AI-powered note-taking that auto-cites sources and exports clean LaTeX/BibTeX, optimized for academic workflows.
- Collaborative lab workspaces with shared notebooks, templates, and versioning to keep teams aligned.
- Privacy-first architecture and academic compliance features to make AI acceptable in institutional settings.

Why now
- LLMs can finally summarize, extract metadata, and format citations reliably enough for real workflows.
- Academic communities are actively adopting AI assistants for literature review and writing, but demand strict privacy.
- Institutions seek productivity gains; lab budgets for software are expanding post-remote collaboration trends.

Target market
- Primary: Graduate students and postdocs in STEM and social sciences; PI-led labs requiring collaborative knowledge management.
- Secondary: Research staff, research engineers, and industry R&D teams.
- TAM proxy: ~5–10M grad students globally; millions more in research roles. If 1M pay at $9/mo, that’s ~$108M ARR potential. Add lab/institution seats and enterprise features for a larger TAM.

Product
- Core features: PDF import (arXiv/PubMed/DOI), structured note generation, auto-citation with style selection, LaTeX/BibTeX/CSL JSON export, tagging and templates for sections (Intro/Methods/Results).
- Collaboration: Lab spaces, shared notebooks, permissions, version history, suggested citations across a shared corpus.
- Integrations: Zotero/Mendeley sync, Overleaf push, Google Drive/Dropbox, arXiv/PubMed ingestion, browser extension for web highlights with instant citations.
- Privacy controls: No training on private data by default, encryption at rest/in transit, data residency options, opt-in analytics only.
- Roadmap highlights
  - Near-term: Zotero and Overleaf plugins, improved citation accuracy (DOI/PMID resolution, deduplication), campus ambassador program.
  - Mid-term: SSO/SAML, audit logs, lab admin console, EU data residency, VPC deployment.
  - Longer-term: Local/offline inference for sensitive notes, API for custom lab pipelines, on-prem for large institutions.

Business model and pricing
- Freemium: core note-taking, limited citations and exports, storage caps.
- Pro: $9/mo (or $90/yr) unlimited citations/exports, advanced templates, collaboration, priority support.
- Lab plan: $6–12 per seat/mo with admin features, SSO, shared corpus, audit logs; annual contracts with volume discounts.
- Enterprise/institution: $15–25 per seat/mo, VPC/on-prem options, custom SLAs, dedicated support.

Traction (based on your inputs)
- 10k MAU; team of 3 PhDs; freemium + $9/mo Pro.
- UVP: auto-citation and LaTeX export; target grad students and labs.
- Challenge: data privacy; Funding: planning $300k pre-seed.

Go-to-market
- Bottom-up student adoption with a campus ambassador program, departmental workshops, and partnerships with university libraries.
