- Top-down lab/institution pilots via PI outreach, research office procurement, and conference presence (ACS, SfN, NeurIPS, ACL, SIGCHI).
- Content and community: Tutorials on literature review, LaTeX workflows, citation best practices; integrate with Overleaf forums and Zotero communities.
- Referral program: Free Pro months for inviting lab members; student discounts.

Competition
- Note-taking: Notion, Obsidian, Roam, Evernote; research assistants: Elicit, Scite, Scholarcy; reference managers: Zotero, Mendeley; writing: Overleaf, Google Docs; general AI tools: ChatGPT, Perplexity.
- Differentiation: Single workflow optimized for academia with trustworthy auto-citation, high-fidelity LaTeX/BibTeX export, and lab-grade collaboration with privacy/compliance baked in.

Moat
- Trust and compliance: Privacy-first design, SOC 2, GDPR/FERPA alignment, data residency, academic-friendly policies.
- Workflow depth: Tight integrations and templates tuned to researcher habits; superior citation accuracy and deduplication.
- Network effects: Shared lab corpora, reusable templates, and cross-paper citation graphs that get better with usage.
- Technical assets: Fine-tuned models for scientific domains; robust metadata resolution pipelines (DOI/PMID/Crossref), local inference options.

Data privacy and security plan
- Architecture: Encrypt data at rest/in transit; zero-retention on model providers; do not train on user content by default.
- Controls: Role-based access, audit logs, SSO/SAML, SCIM; admin policies for labs.
- Compliance: SOC 2 Type I in 6–9 months, Type II thereafter; GDPR DPA and EU data residency; FERPA positioning for educational institutions.
- Enterprise options: VPC/private cloud; on-prem pilot for high-sensitivity labs.
- Transparency: Publish a privacy whitepaper and data flow diagrams; third-party security assessments.

Financials (illustrative)
- Current baseline: 10k MAU. If 5–8% convert to Pro, that’s 500–800 subscribers, MRR ~$4.5k–$7.2k.
- 12-month target: 50k MAU, 8% conversion → 4k Pro subscribers, MRR ~$36k; add 30 lab customers x 10 seats at $12 → ~$3.6k MRR, total ~$39.6k.
- Sensitivity: With stronger campus GTM and enterprise features, 100k MAU and mixed seat revenue could reach $70k–$90k MRR in 18 months.

Milestones (next 12 months)
- Q1: Publish privacy whitepaper; Zotero + Overleaf integrations; 10 lab pilots; MAU 20k; conversion 6%+.
- Q2: SOC 2 Type I complete; lab admin console; SSO; EU data residency; MAU 30k; MRR $15k.
- Q3: VPC deployment; local/offline inference beta; enterprise pilots at 5 institutions; MAU 50k; MRR $30k.
- Q4: SOC 2 Type II; 50 lab customers; MAU 100k; MRR $70k+.

Funding needs and use of funds ($300k pre-seed)
- Privacy/compliance and security engineering: ~$80k (SOC 2 prep/audit, infra hardening, tooling).
- Product/engineering hires: ~$120k (2 hires or contractors focused on integrations and local inference).
- GTM: ~$60k (ambassador program, conferences, content, university partnerships).
- Compute and tooling: ~$20k (RAG stack, vector DB, observability).
- Legal/ops: ~$20k (DPA, contracts, IP, accounting).
- Expected runway: ~12 months.

Key metrics to track
- Activation rate: first import/note within 24h; first auto-citation; first LaTeX export.
- Free→Pro conversion; monthly churn; cohort retention (D30, D90).
- MAU/WAU; notes per user; citations generated; exports per user.
- Lab adoption: number of lab workspaces, seats per lab, shared corpus usage.
- Enterprise pipeline: qualified opportunities, pilot-to-close rate, sales cycle length.
- NPS and support response time; citation accuracy (precision/recall vs ground truth).

Risks and mitigations
- Privacy concerns: Mitigate with transparent policies, SOC 2, VPC/on-prem, zero-retention.
- Platform competition: Differentiate with academic depth and integrations; focus on trust and LaTeX fidelity.
- Institutional procurement friction: Offer easy pilots, edu discounts, and flexible licensing; provide security packages.
- Model reliability: Invest in metadata resolution pipelines, human-in-the-loop checks, and style validators.

Would you like me to refine this plan based on your answers to the questions above, and tailor the financial projections and GTM to your actual conversion, user mix, and integration priorities?

promptPexTests.testinput: company_url: https://www.acme-analytics.com
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
I’ve begun analyzing acme-analytics.com, but I can’t fetch the site content directly in this environment. To move quickly, I’ll propose an initial vision/mission and a YC-style plan based on common patterns for modern analytics platforms, then ask targeted questions to tailor it precisely to ACME Analytics.

Proposed vision and mission (please validate or refine)
- Vision: Put trustworthy, actionable analytics in the hands of every business team.
- Mission: Deliver a unified, easy-to-deploy analytics platform that connects to all your data sources, models metrics consistently, and enables self-service insights, alerts, and embedded analytics—without heavy data engineering.

Key questions to tailor the plan
1) Ideal customer profile: What company size, roles, and verticals do you target (e.g., 50–500 employee mid-market, RevOps/Finance/Data leaders, e-commerce/SaaS/fintech)?
2) Differentiation: How do you win versus Tableau/Power BI/Looker/Metabase and the “modern data stack” (Fivetran + dbt + Snowflake + BI)? What’s uniquely ACME (e.g., speed-to-value, no-code modeling, semantic layer, vertical templates, reverse ETL, embedded analytics)?
3) Product scope: Do you cover data ingestion/ELT, modeling/semantics/metrics layer, dashboards/alerts, governance, embedded analytics, AI/NLQ? Cloud-only or also on-prem/VPC?
4) Integrations: Which warehouses (Snowflake/BigQuery/Redshift), data sources (Salesforce, HubSpot, Stripe, Shopify), and downstream tools (Slack, email, CRMs) are supported?
5) Security/compliance: SOC 2, GDPR, HIPAA? Data residency? SSO/SCIM? Row-level permissions?
6) Go-to-market: PLG motion with freemium? Sales-assisted or enterprise sales? Channels/partners? Current traction (users, logos, pilots)?
7) Pricing: Seats vs usage (rows/compute) vs data sources? Typical ACV? Free vs paid tiers?
8) Team: Who are the founders and current team? Backgrounds, headcount, hiring plan?
9) Financials: Current ARR/MRR, growth rate, churn/NRR, CAC/LTV, runway?
10) Funding: Are you raising now? Target amount, use of funds, and milestones?

Initial YC-style business plan (assumptions to be validated)
Problem
- Companies struggle to turn siloed, fast-growing cloud data into reliable, self-serve insights.
- BI implementations are slow; metrics definitions are inconsistent; dashboards go stale; business teams depend on scarce data engineers.
- The modern data stack is powerful but fragmented and expensive to integrate, govern, and maintain.

Solution
- ACME Analytics provides an end-to-end analytics platform:
  - Easy connectors to common SaaS and databases; optional ELT into major warehouses.
  - A metrics/semantic layer to define reusable, governed metrics once and use everywhere.
  - No-code/low-code modeling and transformation with versioning and testing.
  - Fast dashboarding, alerting, and NLQ (ask questions in natural language).
  - Embedded analytics for products and internal portals; reverse ETL to operational tools.
  - Robust permissioning, audit trails, and compliance controls.

Why now
- Cloud data volumes and operational analytics needs have exploded.
- Teams need speed-to-value and governed metrics without assembling four to six separate tools.
- AI/NLQ can dramatically reduce the barrier to insight, but only if data is modeled and governed.

Market
- TAM: Global business intelligence/analytics software >$40B and growing (double-digit CAGR).
- Beachhead: Mid-market digital businesses (50–500 employees) in e-commerce, SaaS, fintech; buyers include RevOps, Finance, Product, Data leads.
- Expansion: Larger enterprises via governance, security, and embedded analytics; vertical-specific templates.

Product
- Core features:
  - Data: Warehouse integrations (Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift), direct connectors (Salesforce, HubSpot, Stripe, Shopify, GA4), and CDC/ELT options.
  - Modeling: Visual/no-code transforms, semantic/metrics catalog, lineage, testing, versioning.
  - Insights: Dashboards, reports, alerts, NLQ, anomaly detection, forecasting.
  - Delivery: Embedded analytics, reverse ETL to CRM/marketing tools, Slack/email alerts.
  - Governance: Row/column-level security, SSO/SCIM, roles, audit logs; SOC 2 roadmap.
- Deployment: Cloud SaaS with VPC/private deployment option for regulated customers.

Business model
- PLG + sales-assisted:
  - Free tier for small teams; paid tiers by creator seat + usage (compute/rows) or data sources.
  - Mid-market plan: SSO, governance, priority support.
  - Enterprise: VPC deployment, advanced security, premium SLAs.
- Optional professional services for onboarding/metric modeling, channel partner implementations.

Go-to-market
- Bottom-up PLG:
  - Free tier, instant connectors, sample datasets, prebuilt vertical templates.
  - Strong docs, tutorials, community, and content/SEO around “metrics layer,” “self-serve analytics,” and “operational analytics.”
- Sales-assisted:
  - Target RevOps/Finance/Data leaders; ROI-driven demos using customer data.
  - Partnerships with data agencies/SIs; co-selling with warehouse vendors.
  - Case studies highlighting speed-to-value and governed metrics consistency.

Competition and differentiation
- Competitors: Tableau, Power BI, Looker; Metabase, Mode; “assemble-your-own” modern stack (Fivetran/dbt/Snowflake + BI); embedded analytics providers.
- Differentiation (to validate which apply):
  - Integrated stack reduces time-to-value and tooling complexity.
  - Semantic/metrics layer with governance usable by both data and business teams.
  - No-code modeling and vertical templates accelerate onboarding.
  - Operational delivery (alerts, reverse ETL) closes the loop from insight to action.
  - Better TCO vs stitching multiple tools; strong security/compliance posture.

Team
- Founding team: Mix of data engineering, product, and GTM experience.
- Near-term hires: Founding full-stack engineer, data engineer, Head of Marketing/Growth, Sales AE/SDR, Solutions Engineer.
- Advisory: Security/compliance lead; partner ecosystem manager.

Traction and milestones (targets to refine)
- Year 1 targets:
  - 50–100 paying customers; $500k–$1M ARR.
  - Activation rate >40% of sign-ups reaching first dashboard/alert in 7 days.
  - NRR ≥110%; logo churn <2%/month.
  - SOC 2 Type I completed; 30+ connectors; 10 vertical templates.
- Year 2 targets:
  - $2M–$5M ARR; enterprise features (VPC, row-level security at scale); embedded analytics GA.

Financials (example framework)
- Pricing example (to validate):
  - Starter: Free up to 2 creators, limited connectors/usage.
  - Team: $49–$99 per creator/month + usage; SSO add-on.
  - Growth: $499–$1,499/month base + usage; governance, priority support.
  - Enterprise: Custom; VPC, advanced security, SLAs.
- Unit economics assumptions:
  - Gross margin 80–85% (cloud infra, support).
  - Blended CAC via PLG + sales-assisted: $2k–$8k for mid-market customers; payback <12 months.
  - LTV driven by multi-year retention and seat/usage expansion.
- 18-month plan:
  - Use funds to reach $1M–$2M ARR, SOC 2, and enterprise-readiness, setting up for a Seed/Series A.

Funding needs
- Raise: $2M–$3M seed (depending on traction), 18-month runway.
- Use of funds:
  - 40% product/engineering (connectors, metrics layer, governance, AI/NLQ).
  - 25% GTM (growth marketing, sales hires, partner ecosystem).
  - 20% security/compliance (SOC 2, SSO/SCIM, data residency/VPC).
  - 15% cloud infrastructure and support.
- Milestones to hit before next round:
  - ARR ≥$1.5M, NRR ≥110%, SOC 2 complete, 3–5 enterprise logos, partner channel contributing ≥20% of new ARR.

Risks and mitigations
- Crowded market: Focus on speed-to-value, metrics governance, and operational delivery; vertical templates.
- Data security concerns: Invest early in compliance, VPC options, granular permissions.
- Adoption friction: PLG motion, excellent onboarding, prebuilt templates, services partners.
- Integration breadth: Prioritize top 20 connectors, telemetry-driven roadmap.

Core metrics to track
- Time-to-first-insight (TTFI), weekly active teams, dashboard/alert usage, expansion seats/usage.
- Conversion from free to paid, CAC/payback, NRR/logo churn.
- Connector coverage, deployment success rate, support SLAs.

Would you like to refine this plan?
If you share details for the questions above (ICP, product scope, integrations, pricing, traction, team, and funding), I’ll update the vision/mission and tailor each section to ACME Analytics, including specific numbers, GTM tactics, and a financial model aligned with your current stage.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://greenbyte.energy/solutions?ref=yc&utm_source=producthunt
user_intent: Please create a YC-style business plan after asking any tailored questions you need.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Thanks for the URL. Before I draft the YC-style business plan, I need a few tailored details to ensure the plan reflects your actual vision, product, market, and traction.

First, vision and mission
- What is your vision (long-term change you aim to create)?
- What is your mission (what you do today to achieve that vision)?

Customers and problem
- Who is your primary customer segment (e.g., utility-scale renewables owners/operators, IPPs, commercial/industrial energy managers, residential, microgrids, data centers)?
- What top 1–2 painful problems do they face that you solve (e.g., asset underperformance, downtime, fragmented data, forecasting errors, grid constraints, energy cost volatility)?
- How are these problems solved today (status quo/competing tools/services), and why is that insufficient?

Solution and product
- What exactly is your product (software platform, AI optimization engine, hardware + software, managed service)? Key features?
- What outcomes do you deliver (e.g., % increase in energy yield, % reduction in O&M cost, forecasting accuracy improvement, payback period)?
- Key integrations/data sources (SCADA, OEM sensors, EMS/BMS, market data, weather providers)? Any proprietary data?
- Any regulatory/compliance requirements you address (e.g., grid codes, ISO/RTO markets, cybersecurity)?

Market and positioning
- Target geographies and asset types (wind, solar, storage, hybrid)? Size of target market in next 3–5 years?
- Top 3 competitors or alternatives your customers compare you to. How do you outperform them?

Traction and metrics
- Current stage: pilots, paying customers, ARR/MRR, assets under management/monitoring, total MW under management, number of sites?
- Key customer logos or segments you can share.
- Core KPIs: retention/churn, average deployment time, typical ROI or payback for customers.

Business model and pricing
- Pricing model (SaaS per MW/site, tiered features, usage-based, implementation fee, services)?
- Typical contract length and sales cycle.
- Gross margin on software and services.

Go-to-market
- Primary channels (direct sales, channel partners, OEMs, EPCs, utilities)?
- Your ICP (ideal customer profile) and buyer persona (title, budget owner).
- What’s working best today for lead generation (events, referrals, content, partnerships)?

Team and capabilities
- Founders’ backgrounds and domain/technical expertise.
- Current team size and critical roles filled/missing (data science, energy trading, sales, field ops).
- Unique technical advantages (models, IP, algorithms, patents).

Moat and defensibility
- Data, models, or workflows that get better with scale (network/data effects)?
- Switching costs for customers? Key integrations that create lock-in?

Operations and risks
- Implementation requirements (on-prem vs cloud, cybersecurity posture, IT approvals).
- Key risks (regulatory, grid, vendor dependencies, data access, OEM relationships) and mitigations.

Financials and funding
- Current runway, monthly burn, and top cost drivers.
- Funding history and current raise target (amount, instrument, valuation range).
- Planned use of funds and 12–18 month milestones (product, market, team).

Roadmap
- Next 6–12 months: major product releases, integrations, certifications, markets.
- 3-year vision for product and business.

Once you share these, I’ll draft a YC-style business plan tailored to Greenbyte, including problem, solution, market, product, business model, team, financials, traction, and funding needs—then iterate with you to refine it.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://novaenergia.com.br/pt-BR/
site_language: Portuguese
user_note: Our site content is in Portuguese; please ask any follow-up questions in English.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Below is an initial, Y Combinator–style business plan draft for Nova Energia based on typical offerings of Brazilian energy companies with similar positioning. Because I may not capture every detail from your Portuguese site, I’ve noted assumptions and included targeted questions (in English) to refine the plan.

Vision
- Make clean, affordable, and transparent energy the default for Brazilian businesses.
- Empower companies to reduce costs and emissions by opening access to Brazil’s free energy market and renewables, backed by data-driven risk management.

Mission
- Provide end-to-end energy commercialization, portfolio management, and renewable procurement so customers can migrate to the free market, hedge risk, and meet sustainability goals—delivered through a technology-led, service-driven model.

Assumptions (please confirm or correct)
- Nova Energia operates as a Brazilian energy trader/retailer and advisor in the free market (ACL), helping C&I customers migrate from the regulated market (ACR) to ACL.
- Offerings include energy procurement and hedging, risk management, portfolio management (CCEE operations), long-term renewable PPAs, distributed generation (DG/“GD”) subscriptions, and environmental certificates (e.g., I-REC).
- A digital platform provides forecasting, analytics, and billing transparency for clients.
- Primary customers are mid-market and large industrial/commercial consumers; secondary customers may include generators and developers seeking offtake.
- Revenue comes from spreads (R$/MWh), management fees, consulting/origination fees, and potential SaaS subscription for digital tools.

Problem
- Energy costs and volatility are high; migrating and operating in ACL is complex (CCEE, PLD/NEWAVE/DECOMP exposure, collateral requirements).
- Many C&I buyers lack transparent pricing, reliable forecasting, ESG-aligned supply, and professional risk management.
- Generators and developers need credible offtake and structured PPAs to finance projects.

Solution
- One-stop energy commercialization and management: migration to ACL, procurement and hedging, CCEE settlement, digital monitoring, and sustainability solutions.
- Structured renewable PPAs and DG subscriptions to reduce costs and emissions.
- Data-driven risk controls and credit underwriting to protect both sides.
- Optional add-ons: I-REC/renewable certificates, demand-side efficiency, and reporting for ESG.

Why Now
- Regulatory tailwinds toward expanding ACL access (progressive liberalization and market modernization).
- Corporate decarbonization pressures and board-level ESG commitments.
- Rapid growth of DG and utility-scale renewables; new financing structures need professional offtake management.
- Technology and data availability enabling better forecasting/pricing.

Market
- Brazil electricity consumption ~650 TWh/year; ACL already a large share and expanding to mid-sized consumers.
- SAM: C&I customers eligible to migrate or already in ACL seeking better terms, risk management, and ESG solutions.
- SOM: Industries and multi-site commercial chains with meaningful load (e.g., 5–100 GWh/year per client) and appetite for renewables.
- Competitive landscape includes Comerc Energia, Delta Energia, Tradener, Safira, 2W Energia, Enel Trading, Âmbar, and regional DG providers—space remains fragmented, with differentiation possible via technology, transparency, and ESG.

Product
- Energy management: forecasting, procurement, hedging, scheduling, CCEE operations, settlement, billing.
- Renewable PPAs: structured terms (baseload/intermittent, seasonal profiles), price corridors, collars/swaps.
- Distributed Generation: solar plant subscriptions for SMEs and multi-site customers, with consolidated billing and guaranteed discounts versus ACR tariffs.
- Sustainability: I-REC and GHG reporting; renewable-only portfolios; emissions dashboards.
- Platform features: real-time consumption analytics, risk dashboards (VaR, exposure), invoice reconciliation, alerts, and scenario planning.

Business Model
- Core: Spread per MWh on contracted energy (long-term PPAs and short-term balancing).
- Fees: Migration/consulting, portfolio management, CCEE operations, origination fees for PPAs/DG.
- SaaS: Tiered subscription for analytics and reporting (optional).
- Certificates: Margin on I-REC procurement and ESG advisory.

Go-To-Market
- Direct sales to C&I accounts via industry vertical focus (food & beverage, pulp & paper, mining, retail chains, healthcare).
- Partnerships with energy consultants, banks, and equipment/DG installers.
- Content-led marketing: case studies with cost savings and emissions reductions; “ACL migration” playbooks.
- Risk-managed offers: standardized PPAs, guaranteed discounts, transparent price references.

Traction (placeholders; please supply)
- Number of clients under management and total contracted energy (GWh/TWh).
- Average contract tenor and % renewable mix.
- Churn, NPS, and savings delivered versus ACR benchmarks.
- Pipeline: MW under negotiation and signed LOIs.

Team
- Trading and risk management leadership with deep CCEE know-how.
- Origination and structured products expertise for PPAs/DG.
- Data/engineering for forecasting, optimization, and platform development.
- Operations/regulatory specialists for compliance and settlement.

Financials and Unit Economics (illustrative; please supply actuals)
- Revenue streams: spread (R$/MWh), management fees, consulting, SaaS.
- Gross margin per MWh and blended margins by product (PPAs vs DG vs operations).
- Collateral/guarantee requirements for CCEE and working capital needs.
- Credit underwriting processes and default reserves.
- 24-month projection: contracted TWh, revenue, gross margin, operating costs (trading desk, platform dev, sales), and EBITDA breakeven.

Funding Needs (illustrative)
- Raise R$ X million to:
  - Scale origination and client acquisition.
  - Build/expand the digital platform, data models, and integrations (CCEE, metering, billing).
  - Provide working capital for collateral/guarantees and manage PLD exposure.
  - Add structured products capacity (risk limits, credit insurance, diversified portfolio).

Milestones
- 12 months: 250 GWh contracted, 50+ clients, platform v1 live, 70% renewable mix, NPS > 60.
- 24 months: 1 TWh contracted, 150+ clients, platform v2, 85% renewable mix, default rate < 1%, EBITDA breakeven.
- 36 months: 3–5 TWh contracted, regional expansion, integrated certificates marketplace, AI-driven forecasting.

Key Risks and Mitigations
- Price volatility/PLD spikes: disciplined hedging, VAR limits, scenario analysis, diversified portfolio.
- Counterparty credit risk: strict underwriting, collateral, credit insurance, diversified client base.
- Regulatory changes: proactive compliance, legal advisory, flexible contract structures.
- Concentration risk in intermittent renewables: portfolio balancing, storage/Demand Response options, seasonal shaping.

Core KPIs
- Contracted energy (MWh/TWh) and pipeline MW.
- Gross margin per MWh and contribution by product.
- VAR/exposure, hedging ratio, and settlement accuracy.
- Client savings vs ACR benchmark; churn; NPS.
- % renewable supply; certificates delivered.
- Days sales outstanding; defaults; collateral utilization.

Targeted Questions (please answer in English)
1) Business scope
- Are you primarily an energy trader/retailer in ACL, a generator/developer, a DG subscription provider, or a mix?
- Do you operate your own generation assets (solar/wind/SHPP) or source from third parties via PPAs?
- Do you offer environmental certificates (I-REC) and ESG reporting?

2) Customers and traction
- Who are your core customer segments (industry verticals, average annual consumption per client)?
- Current traction: number of active clients, contracted energy (GWh/TWh), average contract term.
- What is your average % renewable supply per client?

3) Revenue model and pricing
- What is the revenue split among spread per MWh, management/consulting fees, DG subscriptions, and any SaaS components?
- Typical spread or fee ranges and margins?
- Do you charge upfront migration fees or performance-based fees?

4) Risk and credit
- How do you manage market risk (hedging policy, VAR limits, mark-to-market, stress tests)?
- Credit policy: collateral requirements for clients, use of credit insurance, default experience.

5) Operations and tech
- Are you a CCEE participant? What systems do you use for scheduling, settlement, and forecasting?
- Do you have a proprietary platform? Key features and integrations (metering, billing, SCADA)?
- Data science capabilities: forecasting load/price, optimization models.

6) Team
- Team size and key roles (trading, origination, risk, ops, engineering).
- Founders’ backgrounds and prior experience in energy/finance/tech.

7) Financials
- Last 12 months revenue and gross margin; operating costs; runway.
- Working capital needs for collateral/guarantees; typical monthly exposure.
- 24–36 month growth targets for clients and contracted energy.

8) Competition and differentiation
- Who do you consider your top competitors?
- What’s your unique value proposition (e.g., tech transparency, renewable guarantees, better pricing, sector focus)?

9) Regulatory and strategy
- Any specific regulatory licenses/permissions you hold?
- Plans for expansion (new regions, products like storage, demand response, carbon markets)?

10) Funding
- Are you raising capital now? Target amount, instrument (equity/debt), and use of funds.
- Key milestones the raise will unlock (clients, TWh, platform releases).

Once you provide these details, I’ll refine the plan with precise market sizing, unit economics, competitive positioning, and a clear funding narrative tailored to Nova Energia.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://tutorlane.app
user_provided_answers:
- revenue_model: 15% commission on each lesson booking
- team: 3 founders (CTO, CEO, COO) + 2 contractors
- challenges: Cold-start on both sides; supply quality assurance
- pricing: Tutors set their hourly rates; minimum $15/hr
- traction: 1,200 students, 300 tutors; $8k GMV last month
- funding_goal: $500k pre-seed to reach PMF
- target_market: US high school students
- mission: Make high-quality 1:1 tutoring accessible and affordable
- vision: A world where every learner gets a personalized mentor
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- A world where every learner gets a personalized mentor.

Mission
- Make high-quality 1:1 tutoring accessible and affordable for US high school students.

What I see from your website
- TutorLane appears to be a two-sided marketplace connecting US high school students with vetted tutors for live 1:1 sessions.
- Tutors set their own hourly rates with a minimum of $15/hour; booking and payments are handled in-platform.
- Positioning emphasizes affordability, accessible matching, and quality assurance for high school subjects and test prep.

Initial questions to tighten the plan
- What is your average hourly rate today, and median rate by subject (e.g., Algebra II, AP Calculus, SAT/ACT, AP Physics)?
- What percent of your 1,200 students are “active” monthly, and what is the average lessons per active student per month?
- Current top acquisition channels: SEO, paid social, school partnerships, referrals, counselor networks? What are your current CACs by channel?
- Tutor quality ops: acceptance rate, vetting steps (credentials, background checks), and target quality metrics (CSAT/NPS thresholds, on-time rate)?
- Do you provide built-in video and lesson notes/progress reports, or integrate Zoom/Google Meet? Any parent dashboard?
- Refund/satisfaction policy for first lesson and trust & safety measures for minors (COPPA compliance, session recordings, parental consent)?
- Growth velocity: last 3 months GMV trend and seasonality (e.g., AP/SAT peaks)?
- Planned geographic focus within the US (national vs. metro-by-metro go-to-market)?

YC-style business plan (draft v1)

Problem
- US high school students need personalized support to master core subjects and prepare for AP/SAT/ACT.
- Existing options are often expensive (>$60/hour), opaque in quality, and hard to schedule. Marketplace options vary widely in tutor quality and lack transparency.
- Parents and students struggle to quickly find vetted, affordable tutors and to measure progress. Tutoring companies struggle with cold-start: balancing supply and demand while maintaining quality.

Solution
- A curated, affordable 1:1 tutoring marketplace focused exclusively on US high school students.
- Fast matching based on subject, availability, price, and quality signals; transparent tutor profiles; easy booking and payment; ongoing progress tracking.
- Quality assurance loop: robust vetting, trial sessions, continuous ratings/NPS, tutor coaching, and clear minimum performance thresholds.

Target market
- Primary: US high school students (grades 9–12) for core subjects and test prep (APs, SAT/ACT).
- TAM: US private tutoring is an ~$8–10B market; high school segment online 1:1 is an estimated $3–5B with growing online penetration post-COVID.
- Beachhead: AP STEM, Algebra/Calculus, Chemistry/Physics, SAT/ACT—time-bound, high-intent demand with predictable seasonal peaks.

Product
- Student-facing: search/match across subjects, tutor profiles (rate, experience, ratings), instant booking, payments, scheduling, messaging, optional parent oversight.
- Tutor-facing: onboarding, credential verification, calendar, pricing, payment, feedback analytics, quality coaching.
- Safety/quality: identity verification, credentials/background checks where applicable, first-lesson satisfaction policy, ongoing performance monitoring.
- Roadmap priorities:
  - AI-powered matching using availability, price, ratings, subject proficiency, and historical outcomes.
  - Progress tracking: lesson notes, goals, weekly summaries to parents; standardized skills rubrics per subject.
  - AP/SAT program flows: multi-session packages aligned to exam calendars; diagnostics to plan study paths.
  - Referral and ambassador programs; counselor portal.
  - Membership tier for families (discounted service fees, concierge matching, priority support).
  - Tutor upskilling: micro-credentials, training modules, QA dashboards.
  - Trust & safety: minor-specific safeguards, COPPA compliance, clear consent flows; option to record sessions for dispute resolution.

Business model
- 15% commission on GMV per lesson booking; tutors set rates (min $15/hour).
- Potential revenue enhancements (to test):
  - Student service fee (e.g., 5%) with transparent value (trust & safety, support, progress reporting) to lift blended take without raising tutor costs.
  - Tiered commission: 20% on first 5 lessons with a new student, then 12–15% thereafter, balancing acquisition and retention.
  - Family membership (e.g., $10–$20/month) for concierge matching, faster support, and reduced service fees.
  - Prepaid packages with mild discount to increase retention and cash flow.
  - Group micro-sessions (2–3 students) for AP review to expand affordability and margin.

Traction
- 1,200 students and 300 tutors on the platform.
- $8k GMV last month; at 15% take rate, ~$1.2k platform revenue.
- Early proof of demand across multiple subjects; clear need to improve density, matching speed, and retention.

Go-to-market
- Demand side:
  - Performance marketing: search ads against “AP [Subject] tutor,” “SAT math tutor,” “algebra tutor near me.” Target peak windows (AP season, SAT test dates).
  - SEO: content hubs for AP guides, practice problems, tutor comparison pages, and local “Best [Subject] Tutors in [City]” landing pages.
  - Ambassador program: school-by-school student reps; referral credits to both students and tutors.
  - Counselor network: relationships with guidance departments; co-branded flyers and counselor referral codes.
  - Parent channels: Facebook/Nextdoor groups; education influencers on TikTok/Instagram; UGC showcasing success stories.
- Supply side:
  - Recruit top college students, licensed teachers, and proven online tutors; highlight flexible hours and reliable earnings.
  - Partnerships with universities and teacher prep programs; targeted outreach to honor societies.
  - Quality-led onboarding: sample lesson, subject diagnostics, micro-credential badges; clear rate guidance by subject/experience.

Quality assurance
- Vetting: identity verification, credential checks, subject proficiency assessments, mock teaching demo; background checks for those working with minors.
- Performance thresholds: maintain ≥4.7 rating, ≥90% on-time rate, low cancellation rate; probation and coaching for borderline performers.
- First-lesson satisfaction guarantee: credit toward a new tutor if expectations aren’t met.
- Ongoing QA: periodic lesson reviews, parent/student NPS, issue resolution SLA; tutor coaching resources.

Unit economics (targets to validate)
- Example assumptions to test:
  - Average hourly rate: $28–$35; 1-hour sessions.
  - Average active student: 3–4 sessions/month during engagement periods.
  - Monthly revenue per active student: ~$12–$21 at 15% take.
  - CAC targets: $25–$60 via paid channels; <$20 via referrals/SEO/ambassadors.
  - Payback: within 1–2 months of activation; LTV ideally $120–$240 revenue over a 6–12 month cycle across multiple subjects/exams.
- Implication: 15% take may constrain margins; add student service fee or tiered commission to lift blended take while preserving affordability.

Competitive landscape
- Wyzant, Varsity Tutors, Preply, Skooli, TakeLessons, local tutoring centers.
- Differentiation:
  - Narrow focus on US high school subjects and exam prep with tailored QA and progress tracking.
  - Transparent pricing with affordability guardrails; faster matching; minor-specific trust & safety.
  - Data-driven outcomes: subject-specific rubrics, progress summaries for parents.

Team
- 3 founders: CEO, CTO, COO; 2 contractors.
- Near-term hires with the pre-seed:
  - Marketplace Operations Lead (trust & safety, QA, supply curation).
  - Growth Lead (performance marketing, SEO, ambassador program).
  - Full-stack Engineer (matching, payments, dashboards).
  - Part-time Subject Lead for AP/SAT curriculum and content.

Financials and milestones (12–18 months)
- Starting point: $8k monthly GMV; ~$1.2k revenue.
- Target by month 12:
  - GMV: $100k+/month; revenue at current take: $15k+/month (or $20k+ with blended service fees).
  - Active students: 3,000+; active tutors: 800+; fill rate ≥85%; time-to-first-lesson <24 hours.
  - Retention: 60% 8-week retention during exam season; average 3+ sessions per active student/month.
  - CAC: <$50 blended; payback ≤1 month; refund rate <5%.
- Month 18:
  - GMV: $200k+/month; revenue $30k–$40k/month; readiness for Seed with clear PMF in at least two verticals (AP STEM, SAT).
- Key KPIs to track:
  - Supply/demand density per subject and metro, match time, first-to-lesson conversion.
  - Tutor Quality Index (ratings, on-time, rebook rate), Student NPS, cohort retention curves.
  - CAC by channel, payback, LTV, refunds/cancellations, trust & safety incidents.

Funding needs
- Ask: $500k pre-seed to reach PMF.
- Use of funds (approximate allocation):
  - Growth experiments and paid marketing: 30%.
  - Product and engineering (matching, progress tracking, mobile-friendly UX): 35%.
  - Trust & safety and QA ops (background checks, vetting tooling, support): 20%.
  - Content/SEO and school/counselor partnerships: 10%.
  - Legal/compliance and runway buffer: 5%.
- Runway: 15–18 months targeting a burn of $25k–$35k/month.

Risks and mitigation
- Cold-start marketplace: go school-by-school and subject-by-subject; seed dense supply in AP math/science and SAT in selected metros.
- Low take rate vs. margins: test service fees and tiered commissions; push prepaid packages and memberships.
- Quality variance: invest in vetting, demo lessons, training, ongoing monitoring; remove consistently underperforming tutors quickly.
- Seasonality: lock in multi-subject progression plans (Algebra → Precalc → SAT), upsell AP packages; build content that captures evergreen demand.

Action plan next 90 days
- Pick 5–10 high schools per metro (2–3 metros) and 4 core subjects + SAT; drive local density with ambassadors and counselor outreach.
- Launch first-lesson satisfaction guarantee and standard QA thresholds; instrument NPS and rebook rates.
- Ship progress reports and simple parent dashboard; add AP/SAT package flows.
- Stand up performance marketing against high-intent keywords; build 50+ SEO pages for AP/school/city combos.
- Referral program: $20 credit both sides; tutor refer-a-tutor bonuses focused on AP/STEM.
- Pricing experiments: introduce a small student service fee and tiered commission for new relationships; measure impact on conversion and margins.

Open questions to refine the plan
- Average hourly rate and distribution by subject; current mix across core subjects vs. AP vs. SAT/ACT.
- Conversion funnel metrics: visitor → sign-up → first booking → second booking; time to first lesson.
- Current retention by cohort (weeks/months) and rebook rate after first session.
- CAC by channel and any current school partnerships; best-performing creatives/messages.
- Finalized trust & safety policies for minors (background checks scope, parental consent, session recording).
- Tutor acceptance rate and performance removal thresholds.
- Any planned geographic focus or constraints; mobile usage vs. desktop.
- Current burn/runway and hiring priorities among the suggested roles.

If you share these details, I can tighten the unit economics, set concrete growth targets per channel, and adjust the roadmap and funding plan to maximize your odds of reaching PMF within this pre-seed. Would you like me to iterate on the plan with deeper financial projections once we confirm average rates, session frequency, CAC, and retention?

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://www.aquatix.io
product_focus: Industrial water monitoring sensors + SaaS dashboard for factories
user_provided_answers:
- revenue_model: Hardware sale + SaaS subscription (per site)
- target_customers: Food & beverage manufacturers
- team: 2 engineers, 1 sales
- challenges: Long sales cycles, on-site pilot installs
- funding_goal: $1.2M for hardware manufacturing and UL certifications
- current_revenue: $12k MRR from 6 pilot sites
- geography: US and Mexico
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- A world where every factory operates with a real-time water intelligence layer—minimizing waste, ensuring compliance, and optimizing production sustainably.

Mission
- Equip food and beverage manufacturers with rugged, plug-and-play water monitoring sensors and an AI-driven SaaS platform to reduce water and chemical use, prevent downtime, and meet regulatory standards across all sites.

Initial understanding from the URL and your inputs
- Aquatix appears to offer industrial water monitoring via proprietary or integrated sensors plus a cloud dashboard designed for factory environments.
- Focus: Food and beverage manufacturers in the US and Mexico.
- Business model: Hardware sale plus per-site SaaS subscription.
- Current traction: 6 pilot sites generating $12k MRR; facing long sales cycles and on-site install requirements.
- Funding goal: $1.2M for manufacturing scale-up and UL certifications.

Targeted questions to complete the plan
1) Product and parameters
- Which parameters do you measure today (e.g., flow, pressure, pH, turbidity, conductivity, temperature, ORP, chlorine, TOC/BOD/COD, metals)?
- Primary use cases: process water, CIP optimization, boilers/cooling towers, wastewater effluent, leak detection?

2) Hardware
- Are sensors proprietary or integrated from OEMs? Typical hardware per site (number of sensors, gateways)?
- Power and communications: mains vs battery; Ethernet/Wi-Fi/Cellular/LoRaWAN; edge compute?
- Install type: inline vs clamp-on; average install time; calibration/maintenance schedule; IP/NEMA rating; hazardous ratings (Class I Div 2)?
- Certifications needed: UL standard (e.g., UL 61010), FCC/CE/RoHS, NSF/ANSI 61, NOM (Mexico)?

3) Software
- Key features: anomaly detection, CIP cycle analytics, compliance reporting, multi-site benchmarking, alerts, mobile app?
- Integrations: SCADA (OPC-UA/Modbus), historians (OSIsoft PI/Ignition), MES/ERP; API availability?
- Data retention and security posture (SOC2/ISO 27001 plans)?

4) Pricing and unit economics
- Hardware ASP per site and gross margin; BOM cost and contract manufacturer?
- SaaS pricing tiers (is $2k/site/month typical?); pilots priced differently?
- Implementation fees, service contracts, warranty terms; expected hardware lifetime.
- CAC, sales cycle length, and payback period you’re targeting.

5) Customers and GTM
- Which subsegments are strongest (breweries, dairy, meat/poultry, beverages bottling, sugar/confectionery)?
- Decision-makers: EHS managers, plant managers, process engineers, corporate sustainability leads?
- Current pipeline size and stage; channel partners or system integrators you work with or target.

6) Traction and outcomes
- Documented ROI: % water/chemical savings, reduced downtime, avoided fines; any case studies or logos?
- Average sensors per site and typical expansion potential after pilot.

7) Team and ops
- Founders’ backgrounds; advisors; immediate hires needed (firmware, data science, field ops, certifications).
- Mexico operations: Spanish UI/documentation, local distributor/integrator relationships, import logistics.

8) Funding and milestones
- Use-of-funds breakdown for the $1.2M; expected runway months.
- 12–18 month milestones (sites, MRR, certifications, product releases) you want to hit for next round.

Initial YC-style business plan (draft)

Problem
- F&B factories lack continuous, reliable water visibility across processes (CIP, boilers, cooling, wastewater), leading to excess water and chemical usage, compliance risk, and unplanned downtime.
- Legacy instrumentation is costly to install/maintain, fragmented by line, and doesn’t deliver actionable analytics or multi-site benchmarking.
- Data sits in SCADA/historians without cross-site insights or predictive alerts.

Solution
- Rugged, rapidly installable sensors and gateways that stream critical water parameters to a cloud SaaS dashboard.
- Vertical-specific analytics for F&B: CIP cycle optimization, effluent compliance alerts, leak detection, consumption benchmarking, automated reports for audits.
- Integrations into plant SCADA/MES and corporate sustainability reporting; multi-site rollups and role-based access.

Why now
- Intensifying water scarcity, regulatory pressure, and corporate ESG reporting in F&B.
- Falling costs for IoT, edge compute, and connectivity; growing comfort with plant-level SaaS.
- Digital transformation budgets are shifting from pilots to standardized deployments.

Product
- Hardware: Industrial-grade sensors and a gateway; clamp-on or inline options; secure connectivity; designed for quick installs and low maintenance.
- Software: Real-time dashboards, anomaly detection, CIP analytics, compliance reports, multi-site benchmarking, alerts; integrations with SCADA/OPC-UA/Modbus; API for data export.
- Differentiation: Faster install, lower total cost of ownership, F&B-specific analytics and reports, multi-site oversight, and measured ROI.

Target customers and use cases
- Food & beverage manufacturers, initially:
  - Breweries/bottling: CIP optimization and leak detection.
  - Dairy/meat processing: Effluent monitoring for compliance; chemical/water savings.
  - Beverage plants: Cooling/boiler water and process water quality control.
- Land-and-expand: Start with one line/area (e.g., CIP), then extend to wastewater, boilers, cooling towers, and multi-site corporate rollouts.

Market
- Initial SAM focus: Medium-to-large F&B plants in the US and Mexico needing water optimization and compliance. Working estimate:
  - US: ~4,000–6,000 plants with relevant scale.
  - Mexico: ~800–1,500 plants.
  - If average SaaS is ~$24k/site/year and hardware average initial sale is $30k–$50k/site:
    - Annual software SAM ≈ $120M–$180M; initial hardware SAM ≈ $150M–$300M.
- TAM expands with adjacent verticals (beverage suppliers, pulp & paper, chemicals), and by adding modules (steam/cooling, wastewater, chemicals dosing).

Business model
- Hardware sale per site (upfront or financed) plus SaaS subscription per site/month; optional implementation fee and service contracts.
- Indicative pricing (to confirm):
  - Hardware per site: $30k–$50k; 40–55% gross margin target.
  - SaaS per site: ~$2k/month; 80–90% gross margin.
- Tiered SaaS by sensors/data volume/features; discounts for multi-site multi-year agreements.

Go-to-market
- Direct sales to plant and EHS managers; offer standardized pilot package with guaranteed timelines and ROI targets.
- Channel partners: System integrators, water treatment OEMs, CIP equipment vendors (e.g., integrators serving breweries/dairy), and sustainability consultants.
- Content-led inbound: compliance templates, ROI calculators, case studies; target associations (BA, IDFA, NAMI).
- Land-and-expand motion: single plant line → full plant → corporate rollouts across regions; reference wins in US to unlock Mexico corporate groups.

Traction
- 6 pilot sites; $12k MRR (~$2k/site/month).
- Operating in US and Mexico; early proof of cross-border deployments.
- Addressing long sales cycles and on-site installs; moving toward repeatable pilot and deployment playbooks.

Team
- 2 engineers (hardware/firmware/cloud) and 1 sales. Plan to add:
  - Field applications engineer for installs/support.
  - Certifications/quality lead.
  - Data scientist/ML for anomaly detection and CIP analytics.
  - Partnerships lead for system integrators/OEMs.

Product roadmap (12 months)
- Q1–Q2: UL/FCC/CE certifications; standardized pilot kit; SCADA/OPC-UA connector; Spanish localization.
- Q2–Q3: CIP optimization module v2 with measurable savings; compliance reporting templates; mobile app.
- Q3–Q4: Multi-site benchmarking and corporate dashboards; inventory financing for hardware; predictive maintenance for sensors.

Financial plan (illustrative; to refine with your numbers)
- Starting MRR: $12k (6 sites).
- Target 18 months: 60–80 sites live, $120k–$160k MRR.
- Hardware revenue: 60–80 sites x $40k/site ≈ $2.4M–$3.2M cumulative; blended gross margin improving with scale.
- Operating expenses: grow from ~$80k/month to ~$150k/month as team scales.
- Runway: $1.2M funds plus growing gross margin could support 15–18 months with disciplined hiring and inventory turns.

Funding needs and use of funds
- Total: $1.2M seed.
- Use:
  - 40% manufacturing ramp and inventory (CM setup, test fixtures, yield improvements).
  - 20% certifications (UL, FCC, CE, NSF/NOM) and QA processes.
  - 20% engineering hires (firmware, data, integrations) and product development.
  - 10% sales/implementation (pilot kits, travel, field tools).
  - 10% contingency and working capital.
- Milestones to unlock next round:
  - Certifications complete; 50+ sites; $100k+ MRR; 2–3 channel partnerships delivering ≥20% of new logos; documented ROI case studies.

Competition and differentiation
- Competitors: Legacy instrumentation and analytics providers (Hach, Xylem, Endress+Hauser), SCADA/historian vendors, and integrators.
- Your edge: Faster install, lower TCO, F&B-specific analytics, corporate multi-site dashboards, and clear ROI (CIP water/chemical savings, compliance assurance).

Risks and mitigation
- Long sales cycles: Standardize pilots, pre-approved vendor status, corporate-level agreements, ROI guarantees tied to measurable KPIs.
- On-site installs: Pilot kits with clamp-on sensors and guided remote assist; train partner integrators; clear safety/compliance SOPs.
- Sensor fouling/reliability: Self-cleaning designs, calibration protocols, redundancy; service SLAs.
- Certification delays: Parallel testing, experienced labs, staged rollouts where certification isn’t required.
- Cross-border logistics: Local distributor partnerships, NOM-certified SKUs, Spanish-language support.

Key KPIs to track
- Site count, MRR, net revenue retention (land-and-expand).
- Install cycle time and cost per install.
- Alert precision/recall, measured savings (water, chemicals, fines avoided).
- Hardware gross margin, inventory turns, failure rates.
- Sales cycle length, CAC, payback period.
- % revenue via partners vs direct.

Actionable next steps
- Package a 6–8 week “Rapid Pilot” with fixed scope, ROI goals, and a conversion discount to annual SaaS.
- Build a quick ROI calculator tailored to CIP and effluent compliance for F&B plants.
- Secure 2–3 system integrator partners in US and Mexico; train them with pilot kits.
- Prioritize one subsegment (e.g., breweries) to create 2–3 strong case studies, then scale horizontally.
- Define certification timeline and publish a compliance matrix for prospects.

Would you like to refine this plan?
- Please share answers to the questions above, plus:
  - Hardware ASP and BOM costs; target gross margins.
  - SaaS pricing tiers and any implementation/service fees.
  - Typical sensors per site and install time.
  - Pipeline size and average sales cycle length.
  - Documented ROI metrics from pilots.
Once I have these, I’ll update the market sizing, unit economics, milestones, and GTM to produce a tighter, investor-ready YC-style plan.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://careloop.health
user_provided_answers:
- regulatory: HIPAA compliant; not a medical device
- revenue_model: Per-employee per-month (PEPM) via employers
- team: 1 MD, 1 RN, 2 engineers, 1 PM
- challenges: Employer benefits broker channel access
- traction: 8 employer customers; 6,400 covered lives
- funding_goal: $2M seed
- mission: Deliver 24/7 virtual care to shift workers
- vision: Universal, on-demand care for every worker
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
Universal, on-demand care for every worker.

Mission
Deliver 24/7 virtual care to shift workers.

Initial website-based understanding
Careloop Health appears to provide always-on, chat-first virtual care targeted at shift-based workforces (manufacturing, logistics, retail, hospitality, etc.). The value proposition likely focuses on immediate access, care navigation, and closing the loop on referrals, prescriptions, and lab orders, optimized for off-hours when traditional care is unavailable. Distribution seems employer-sponsored, priced per employee per month.

If any of the below is off versus what’s on your site, I’ll adjust after your feedback.

Y Combinator–style business plan (draft 1)

Problem
- Shift workers have limited access to timely care due to nonstandard hours, transportation barriers, and clinic availability.
- Employers face absenteeism, avoidable ER/urgent care spend, and lower productivity when workers can’t access fast, affordable care.
- Existing telehealth is often appointment-based, slow to respond off-hours, and not optimized for chat-first, multilingual, or low-latency triage.
- Care navigation breaks down after the “first visit”—workers struggle to complete referrals, get labs, and pick up medications.

Solution
- 24/7, on-demand, chat-first virtual care tailored to shift workers, with fast response time and escalation to video when needed.
- Integrated care navigation: e-prescribing, labs/imaging orders, referral scheduling, and follow-up to “close the loop.”
- Employer-sponsored benefit with easy onboarding, multilingual support, and outcomes reporting (ER avoidance, time-to-response, satisfaction).
- Not a medical device; fully HIPAA compliant. Clinical model combines RN triage with MD oversight to deliver safe, efficient care.

Product
- Core: Secure chat with immediate clinician response; asynchronous messaging optimized for noisy environments and short breaks.
- Escalations: Video visits when clinically necessary; e-prescribing (non-controlled), lab/imaging orders, and referral scheduling.
- Navigation: Follow-up reminders, care plans, and “closed loop” tracking until the care task is completed.
- Integrations: Employer HRIS/benefits portals, SSO, PBM for pharmacy, LabCorp/Quest for labs, and local networks for urgent/primary care referrals.
- Analytics: Employer dashboards with utilization, ER avoidance, productivity impact, and satisfaction/NPS.
- Languages: English plus Spanish; add more as needed for workforce composition.
- Compliance: HIPAA, state licensure, malpractice coverage; data security and audit trails.

Why now
- Post-COVID normalization of virtual care; workers expect instant access and employers expect measurable ROI.
- Tight labor markets make worker benefits and convenience differentiators for retention.
- Rising ER/urgent care costs and self-insured employers seeking immediate savings via virtual care redirection.
- Asynchronous chat care models have matured to deliver quality at lower cost per consult.

Market
- US workforce ~167M; shift/nonstandard hours workers conservatively 30–40M.
- SAM: Employers with large shift-based populations in manufacturing, logistics, retail, hospitality, healthcare services—estimated 10–15M covered lives addressable through employer benefits.
- Pricing benchmark: $6–12 PEPM typical for chat-first urgent care/navigation solutions.
- TAM (illustrative): 40M shift workers x $8 PEPM x 12 months ≈ $3.8B annually.

Business model and unit economics (assumptions; will refine with your data)
- Revenue: PEPM via employers; optional add-ons (labs, care navigation premium, multilingual support).
- Price: Example $8 PEPM.
- Utilization: 0.2–0.5 visits per member per month (VPM) for shift workers.
- Cost per consult: $8–15 with RN-led triage + MD oversight; target < $10 with asynchronous workflows and playbooks.
- For 1,000 members at $8 PEPM:
  - Revenue: $8,000/month.
  - At 0.35 VPM: ~350 consults/month.
  - If $10 cost per consult: $3,500 COGS; gross margin ~56%.
- Sensitivities: Profitability scales with lower cost per consult, efficient escalation, and utilization management.

Go-to-market
- Direct sales to employers in verticals with high shift populations (e.g., manufacturing, distribution centers, large retail/hospitality chains).
- Broker/consultant channel:
  - Create broker enablement kits: ROI case studies, demo playbooks, co-marketing assets.
  - Comp structure: Broker fees/SPIFs aligned with PEPM; performance-based bonuses tied to adoption and ROI metrics.
  - Partner with national and regional firms; host webinar series and demo days focused on ER avoidance and productivity impact.
- Land-and-expand:
  - Start with a single site/region; prove ER avoidance and satisfaction; expand to full workforce.
  - Offer pilots (3–6 months) with guaranteed SLA: time-to-first-response < 2 minutes, close-the-loop completion > 85%.
- Integrations: Simple HRIS/benefits onboarding; provide QR codes, posters, and SMS onboarding for frontline workers.

Competition and differentiation
- Incumbents: Teladoc, Included Health, Doctor On Demand, Crossover Health, CirrusMD (notably chat-first employers), Eden Health, K Health, 98point6 (now-wrapped), Firefly, Carbon.
- Differentiators:
  - Built-for-shift design: chat-first, sub-2-minute response, off-hours ops, multilingual.
  - Close-the-loop navigation as the core product, not a bolt-on; measurable completion metrics.
  - Employer-aligned ROI reporting specific to ER avoidance, return-to-work speed, and reduced absenteeism.
  - Seamless workplace onboarding for non-desk employees (QR codes, signage, SMS).

Traction
- 8 employer customers; 6,400 covered lives.
- HIPAA compliant; not a medical device.
- Revenue model: PEPM via employers.

Team
- Current: 1 MD, 1 RN, 2 engineers, 1 PM.
- Near-term hires:
  - Head of Clinical Ops and Quality (protocols, outcomes, licensure expansion).
  - Head of Employer/Broker Sales (national broker relationships).
  - Customer Success Manager (adoption at sites; materials, training).
  - Additional RNs/APPs; part-time MDs for oversight; Spanish-speaking clinicians.
  - Security/Compliance lead (SOC 2 roadmap if not already started).

Milestones (next 12–18 months)
- Customers/lives: 50 employers; 50,000–75,000 covered lives.
- Broker partnerships: 5–10 signed; at least one national distributor.
- Product SLAs: <2 minute median response; >85% close-the-loop completion; NPS >70.
- Outcomes: ER/urgent care redirection rate 20–40%; average time-to-return-to-work improvement quantified.
- Licensure: 50-state coverage or targeted multi-state footprint covering top customer concentrations.
- Financial: >$2–3M ARR; gross margin >60%; CAC payback <12 months.
- Compliance: SOC 2 Type I; begin Type II; finalize malpractice panel and credentialing.

Financials and funding
- Funding goal: $2M seed.
- Use of funds (approximate):
  - 35% clinical ops and staffing (RN coverage, MD oversight, licensure expansion).
  - 25% engineering/product (chat platform, escalations, analytics, employer dashboards, multilingual).
  - 20% GTM (broker channel, sales, customer success, marketing assets).
  - 10% compliance/security (SOC 2, audits, privacy program).
  - 10% working capital and contingencies.
- Forecast (illustrative, to be refined with price/utilization):
  - Today: 6,400 lives. At $8 PEPM → ~$614k ARR.
  - 12 months: 50k lives → ~$4.8M ARR at $8 PEPM.
  - Gross margin improves with scale and protocol optimization.

Regulatory and clinical
- HIPAA compliant; not a medical device.
- Ensure appropriate state licensure, credentialing, and malpractice coverage.
- Clinical governance: Evidence-based protocols for common conditions; clear escalation thresholds; QA reviews; incident reporting.
- Data privacy/security: Access controls, audit logs, encryption; SOC 2 roadmap.

Risks and mitigations
- Broker channel access: Create compelling broker incentives and turnkey materials; deliver rapid, measurable ROI for case studies.
- Utilization spikes: Staff flex pools; protocol-driven triage; asynchronous workflows to control costs.
- Competitive overlap: Focus on shift-worker UX and navigation outcomes; guarantee response SLAs.
- Multi-state ops complexity: Prioritize employer geographies; partner for licensure; use medical group entities to streamline.
- Employer adoption: Onsite activation campaigns; SMS onboarding; union/manager engagement.

Key KPIs
- Time-to-first-response (median and 90th percentile).
- Close-the-loop completion rates (Rx filled, labs done, referrals attended).
- ER/urgent care redirection rate; per-member ER spend reduction.
- Utilization (VPM), cost per consult, gross margin.
- NPS and CSAT; adoption/activation rates.
- Sales cycle length; CAC; CAC payback.
- Employer retention/churn; expansion rate.

Tailored questions to refine the plan
1) Pricing: What is your current PEPM price range and contract term length?
2) Clinical scope: What conditions do you cover and which do you exclude? Do you prescribe controlled substances at all?
3) Care model: Is care primarily asynchronous chat with optional video escalation? What are your median response times today?
4) Licensure footprint: Which states are you currently covering, and what’s the roadmap to nationwide coverage?
5) Languages: Which languages are supported today? What % of users require non-English support?
6) Outcomes: Do you have measured ER/urgent care avoidance rates, time-to-return-to-work improvements, and NPS?
7) Utilization: What is your current VPM and activation rate among covered lives?
8) Costs: What is your average cost per consult and staffing ratios (RN:members, MD oversight hours)?
9) Sales: Average sales cycle length; direct vs. broker-sourced deals; any signed broker partnerships?
10) Verticals: Which employer verticals are performing best (manufacturing, logistics, retail, hospitality, healthcare)?
11) Integrations: Which HRIS/benefits platforms are you integrated with? Any PBM, lab, or referral network partners?
12) Security: Status of SOC 2 or other certifications, and any enterprise security requirements you’ve encountered.
13) Differentiation: How do you position against CirrusMD/Teladoc/Included Health in head-to-head broker comparisons?
14) Traction: Current ARR and gross margin, and any cohort adoption data (expansion rates, churn)?
15) Roadmap: Any planned features (e.g., medication delivery to workplace, behavioral health add-on, injury triage)?

Would you like me to adjust the plan based on your answers and any clarifications from your website? I can also build a simple financial model and broker GTM materials once I have pricing, utilization, and outcome data.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://www.cryptoclear.finance/#home
user_provided_answers:
- regulatory: Non-custodial; registered as MSB in US
- revenue_model: 0.25% swap fees; premium KYC services for institutions
- team: 4 developers, 1 compliance officer
- challenges: Building user trust; on/off-ramp partnerships
- target_market: LATAM retail investors
- traction: 35k MAU; $12M monthly trading volume
- funding_goal: $3M seed
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision
- Enable anyone in LATAM to access transparent, compliant, and low-cost crypto finance without relying on custodians.

Mission
- Build the most trusted non-custodial swap and fiat on/off-ramp platform for LATAM retail, combining simple UX, institutional-grade compliance, and local payment integrations.

A few tailored questions to fill critical gaps
1) Product and tech
- What is the core product scope today: non-custodial swap aggregator, cross-chain bridge, fiat on/off-ramp aggregator, or all three?
- Which chains/tokens are supported (e.g., Ethereum, Polygon, BNB Chain, Solana)? Is stablecoin access a primary use case?
- Have your smart contracts been audited? By whom? Are any components open-source?
- Do you offer mobile app(s), or is it web-only? Which wallets are supported (e.g., MetaMask, Trust Wallet, WalletConnect)?
2) Geography and ramps
- Which LATAM countries are live or prioritized (e.g., Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Colombia, Peru)?
- What is the status of on/off-ramp partnerships (e.g., Pix in Brazil, SPEI in Mexico, PSE in Colombia)? Any signed agreements or go-live timelines?
3) Differentiation and users
- In one sentence, what is your unique value proposition versus centralized exchanges (Binance, Bitso), local brokers, and DEXs (Uniswap)?
- What are the top use cases for retail users (savings in stablecoins, remittances, trading, DeFi yields)?
- Average transaction size, repeat rate, and 30/90-day retention?
4) Compliance
- Beyond US MSB, what local registrations or legal opinions exist in target countries? How do you approach non-custodial + fiat integration compliance?
- Which providers do you use for AML/sanctions screening and blockchain analytics (e.g., Chainalysis, TRM)?
- For premium KYC services: pricing model, # of institutional clients today, and pipeline?
5) Go-to-market and metrics
- Primary acquisition channels (influencers, community, paid ads, partnerships) and CAC?
- Current conversion rates (visitor → wallet connect → swap → repeat), and top drop-off points?
6) Team and hiring
- Founders’ backgrounds and roles; do you plan to add BD/partnerships lead in LATAM, marketing/community, and local compliance counsel?
- Any advisors with banking or payments experience in LATAM?

Initial YC-style business plan (draft based on your site + answers; we will refine after your feedback)

Problem
- LATAM retail faces inflation, capital controls, and limited access to low-cost, reliable financial tools.
- Centralized exchanges add custody risk and often lack seamless local ramps, while pure DEXs don’t solve fiat access or compliance needs.
- Trust and regulatory clarity are persistent barriers; users need simple, safe, and compliant ways to move between fiat and stablecoins/crypto.

Solution
- Non-custodial swap platform focused on LATAM retail, with institutional-grade compliance options.
- Aggregated liquidity for low-fee swaps (0.25%) and a premium KYC layer for institutions and higher limits.
- Localized fiat on/off-ramp partnerships to bridge users directly to stablecoins and back to local currency.
- Transparent operations: audits, open communication, and education to build trust.

Product
- Web-based non-custodial swaps with wallet connect; focus on top chains and stablecoins (e.g., USDC, USDT). Cross-chain capability if supported.
- Compliance suite: KYC tiers, AML/sanctions screening, transaction risk scoring, and address filtering for flagged wallets.
- Localized fiat rails (partners) integrated via bank transfers and instant payment networks (e.g., Pix/SPEI/PSE) for cash-in/cash-out.
- UX tailored to LATAM: local currency display, Spanish/Portuguese, educational content, fee transparency, and slippage protection.
- Security: audited smart contracts, formal incident response, clear disclosures, and non-custodial architecture.

Target market
- Primary: LATAM retail investors and savers seeking stablecoins and simple swaps (Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Colombia, Peru).
- Secondary: Small businesses and professional traders needing compliant access and higher limits.
- Tertiary: Institutions requiring premium KYC/compliance and potential white-label ramp solutions.

Market size
- LATAM has >650M population with rising crypto adoption. Stablecoin demand for savings/remittances is strong.
- TAM: broader crypto access in LATAM; SAM: retail stablecoin and swap users in top 5 countries; SOM: users reachable via local ramps and community channels.
- Benchmarks: Local leaders (Bitso, Mercado Bitcoin) process large volumes; DEXs see significant activity but lack fiat access/compliance focus.

Competition
- Centralized exchanges: Binance, Bitso, Mercado Bitcoin, Coinbase (custodial, strong brand, but higher custody risk).
- DEXs/aggregators: Uniswap, 1inch (great liquidity, limited fiat and compliance support).
- P2P marketplaces and local brokers: variable fees, fragmented trust.
- Differentiation: non-custodial + local fiat ramps + compliance stack + LATAM-first UX and language support.

Business model
- 0.25% swap fee on crypto-crypto volume.
- Premium KYC/compliance services for institutions (subscription or tiered per-user pricing).
- Potential revenue share with on/off-ramp partners and spread on fiat conversion where permitted.
- Future: B2B/white-label compliance/ramp APIs for fintechs and neobanks.

Traction (provided)
- 35k MAU; $12M monthly trading volume.
- Implied monthly fee revenue at 0.25%: ~$30k before other revenues.
- Early proof of demand; opportunity to grow via ramps and trust-building.

Go-to-market
- Country sequencing: prioritize Brazil (Pix), Mexico (SPEI), then Colombia/Argentina based on partner readiness and regulatory clarity.
- Partnerships: local payment processors, neobanks, cash-out networks; co-marketing with wallet projects.
- Community-led growth: Spanish/Portuguese content, influencers, ambassadors, Telegram/Discord groups, educational webinars focused on stablecoin safety and use cases.
- Trust signals: security audits, transparency reports, compliance certifications, public roadmap, and responsive support.

Regulatory and compliance
- Non-custodial model and US MSB registration already in place.
- Implement robust AML/sanctions screening; maintain KYC tiers aligned to local risk thresholds.
- Obtain legal opinions per country; partner with locally licensed ramp providers to minimize licensing burden.
- Clear terms, disclosures, and risk policies; incident reporting and SAR where required.

Team
- Current: 4 developers, 1 compliance officer.
- Near-term hires: LATAM BD/partnerships lead, local compliance counsel(s), marketing/community lead, support ops, and a security engineer.
- Advisors: target banking/payments experts and local regulatory counsel.

Financials (initial view; will refine with your inputs)
- Current revenue: swap fees ~$30k/month at $12M volume; add premium KYC revenue when available.
- Cost drivers: engineering salaries, infra (nodes/RPC, analytics), compliance tools, audits, legal, marketing, partner integration fees.
- Seed plan targets (illustrative): scale monthly volume to $60M+ within 12–18 months, yielding ~$150k/month fees; add premium KYC/enterprise to diversify to $50k+/month.
- Unit economics to validate: CAC vs. margin per active user; conversion to repeat usage; ramp integration ROI.

Funding needs
- Goal: $3M seed (SAFE preferred).
- Use of funds (example allocation; adjust based on your priorities)
  - 35% engineering and security (mobile app, cross-chain, audits)
  - 25% partnerships and country launches (integration fees, BD hires)
  - 20% compliance/legal (local counsel, licensing opinions, AML tools)
  - 15% growth (community, education, influencers, content)
  - 5% contingency and working capital
- Runway: 18–24 months; key milestones below.

Key risks and mitigations
- Regulatory shifts: mitigate via local counsel, partner with licensed ramps, maintain non-custodial architecture.
- Trust: mitigate with audits, transparency reports, responsive support, and educational content.
- Partner dependency: diversify ramp providers per country; build redundancy.
- Competition: differentiate on UX, fees, local rails, and compliance; focus on stablecoin/fiat bridge use cases where DEXs/CEXs under-serve.
- Fraud/AML: strong screening, transaction limits for non-KYC users, real-time monitoring.

12–18 month milestones
- Integrate fiat ramps in 3–4 priority countries and achieve on/off-ramp GMV of $20M+/month.
- Grow to 200k MAU and $60M+ monthly crypto-crypto volume; improve 30-day retention by 2x.
- Launch mobile app; complete at least two independent security audits.
- Release premium KYC/compliance suite; onboard 50+ institutional clients or B2B partners.
- Establish local language support and 24/7 help desk; publish quarterly transparency reports.

Core KPIs to track
- MAU, DAU, and activation rate (wallet connect → first swap).
- Monthly trading volume; stablecoin inflow/outflow via ramps.
- Fee revenue; take rate; blended margin.
- Retention (30/90-day), repeat swaps per user, cohort LTV.
- CAC by channel; payback period; conversion funnel.
- % of volume via local ramps; number of active ramp partners per country.
- Compliance metrics: KYC conversion, flagged transactions, false positives.

Would you like to refine or enhance this plan?
- Please share answers to the questions above (chains supported, current countries, ramp partners and timelines, premium KYC pricing/clients, audits, mobile/web, CAC/retention). With those, I’ll tighten the market sizing, financial projections, hiring plan, and milestones to produce a YC-ready version for fundraising.

promptPexTests.testinput:
company_url: https://stealthgrid.ai
site_login_required: true
brief_description: Zero-trust network overlay for remote-first enterprises
user_provided_answers:
- revenue_model: Per-seat annual contracts
- team: 2 founders (ex-Google, ex-Cloudflare)
- challenges: Communicating differentiation without disclosing IP
- target_market: 200–2,000 employee tech companies
- mission: Make corporate networks invisible to attackers
- vision: Default secure connectivity for the internet
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Vision: Default secure connectivity for the internet.
Mission: Make corporate networks invisible to attackers.

Note: I couldn’t access your site content due to login requirements, so I’ve based this on your brief and answers. To tailor the plan precisely, a few focused questions:

- Product/architecture
  - Is your overlay agent-based on endpoints/servers? Any gateways or outbound-only connectors?
  - What identity providers and MDM/EDR systems do you integrate with (Okta/Azure AD, CrowdStrike, Jamf, Intune)?
  - How do you enforce zero trust (continuous device/user posture, microsegmentation, ephemeral credentials, just-in-time access)?
  - Do you support peer-to-peer paths (WireGuard-like) or route via your cloud? Any on-prem option?
  - Typical deployment time for a 500-user pilot? Platforms supported (Windows/macOS/Linux/iOS/Android)?

- Differentiation and proof
  - What are the key publicly demonstrable properties that don’t reveal IP (e.g., no inbound ports, outbound-only, ephemeral addresses, traffic never exposed to public internet)?
  - Any third-party validation (pen tests, red-team reports, SOC 2 Type II timeline)?

- GTM and pricing
  - Current or target price per seat and tiers? Minimums and typical ACV?
  - Who is the buyer and champion (CISO, Head of IT, Platform Engineering)?
  - Current pipeline or pilots? Average sales cycle length?

- Market focus
  - Beachhead verticals within tech (SaaS, fintech, gaming, devtools)? Any compliance drivers (SOC2, ISO 27001, HIPAA)?
  - Geographic focus and data residency requirements?

- Ops
  - Planned SLAs (availability, latency), support model, and deployment assistance?
  - Any open-source components, community strategy, or partner channels (MSSPs/SIs)?

Initial YC-style business plan (draft)

Problem
- Remote-first mid-market tech companies (200–2,000 employees) struggle with legacy VPNs and gateway-centric “zero trust” that still expose attack surface, enable lateral movement, and add operational friction.
- Attackers exploit exposed services, flat networks, and long-lived credentials; defenders need provably invisible networks, strong segmentation, and simple, scalable operations.

Solution
- A zero-trust network overlay that makes corporate networks non-discoverable and non-reachable to unauthorized entities.
- Core principles:
  - Identity- and posture-driven access for users, devices, and services.
  - Outbound-only connectivity; no inbound ports or public exposure.
  - Ephemeral, just-in-time pathways with microsegmentation; default deny.
  - Least-privilege policies as code; strong auditability.
  - High-performance edge with minimal latency; cross-platform agents and lightweight connectors.
- Outcomes:
  - Eliminate VPNs and exposed gateways.
  - Kill lateral movement and shrink blast radius.
  - Reduce operational burden with simple rollout and policy automation.

Product
- Endpoint/connector agents for users, servers, services; central policy plane integrated with SSO/IdP and device posture.
- Policy-as-code with templates for common roles, services, and environments (Prod/Stage/Dev).
- Integrations: IdPs (Okta, Azure AD), MDM/EDR (Intune, CrowdStrike), cloud (AWS/GCP/Azure), logging/SIEM (Splunk, Datadog).
- Admin features: fleet management, posture checks, dynamic groups, traffic logs, audit trails, break-glass flows.
- Security/compliance roadmap: SOC 2 Type II within 12 months; encryption in transit/endpoints; third-party red-team; privacy-by-design.

Differentiation (message without revealing IP)
- Outcomes and testable properties, not internals:
  - No inbound exposure: overlay uses outbound-only paths; nothing to scan or DDoS.
  - Ephemeral access: paths and credentials expire quickly; limit replay/lateral movement.
  - Microsegmented by identity: services are reachable only to authorized identities; others see nothing.
  - Fast rollout: hours to pilot; days to production for 500–1,000 users.
- Position against incumbents:
  - Cloudflare/Zscaler/Prisma: gateway/SWG-centric; still expose access edges and add latency.
  - Tailscale/ZeroTier/NetBird: great for teams; less enterprise-grade posture/policy/audit at scale.
  - Teleport/Okta PA: strong identity/app access; limited full-network invisibility at scale.
- Proof strategy: “black-box” demos (unauthorized scan finds nothing), red-team reports, side-by-side latency and reliability benchmarks.

Target customers
- Mid-market tech companies (SaaS/devtools/fintech/gaming) with 200–2,000 employees; remote or hybrid; modern IdP/MDM stack; cloud-heavy and developer-centric.
- Beachhead: platform engineering and security teams replacing VPNs, segmenting prod, securing third-party access.

Go-to-market
- Land-and-expand:
  - Start with a 100–300 user pilot (engineering + SRE + security) and a few critical services/segments.
  - Show measurable wins: zero exposed attack surface, time-to-access under 2 minutes, reduced support tickets, lower latency vs VPN.
- Sales motion:
  - Top-down to CISO/Head of IT with ROI and risk reduction; bottom-up champion in platform/security.
  - Offer 30–60 day pilot with guided deployment and success metrics.
- Channels:
  - MSSPs/SIs for deployment; cloud marketplaces (AWS/GCP/Azure) for procurement.
  - Thought leadership on “invisible networks” and anti-lateral-movement design; case studies.
- Pricing (assumptions; confirm):
  - Per-seat annual contracts; target $18–$30/user/month billed annually; 500-seat average → $108k–$180k ACV.
  - Add-ons: server/service connectors, premium compliance pack, priority support.

Business model
- High gross margin SaaS (85–90%); annual contracts with prepay and multi-year discounts.
- Upsells through additional segments, server connectors, higher security tier, and expanded user groups.
- Professional services optional for complex environments (keep <15% of revenue).
- Key metrics: time-to-pilot (days), pilot-to-paid conversion (>60%), NRR (>120%), support ticket rate, policy change velocity.

Market
- Zero trust network access (ZTNA) and secure connectivity market is large and growing (multi-billion, double-digit CAGR).
- Mid-market tech is a fast-adopting subset with clear pain (remote work, breach risk, engineer productivity).
- Expand later to healthcare/fintech with compliance packs and to larger enterprises after mid-market traction.

Team
- 2 founders (ex-Google, ex-Cloudflare) with deep network/security experience.
- Near-term hires (first 12 months):
  - Founding engineer (agent/low-level networking).
  - Security/infra engineer (policy plane, posture, integrations).
  - Product designer (admin UX, policy UX).
  - Solutions engineer (pilots, customer success).
  - AE with security SaaS background.
  - Compliance lead (SOC 2, ISO 27001).
- Advisory: CISO/executive advisors for credibility and enterprise sales.

Regulatory/compliance
- SOC 2 Type II within 12 months; ISO 27001 in 18–24 months.
- Data residency options for EU; privacy-first telemetry.
- Documented SDLC, vulnerability management, incident response.

Financials (12–24 month sketch; adjust with your pricing)
- Assumptions:
  - Price: $24/user/month billed annually.
  - Avg deal: 500 seats; ACV ≈ $144k.
  - Sales cycle: 2–4 months; pilot conversion 60%.
- Year 1:
  - 12 paying customers by month 12 → ~6,000 seats → ARR ≈ $1.7M.
  - Burn: ~$250k/month with a lean team (~10 FTE).
- Year 2:
  - 35 customers cumulatively → ~17,500 seats → ARR ≈ $5.0M.
  - NRR 120% via expansions; target gross margin 88%.
- Unit economics:
  - CAC payback <12 months; blended CAC per customer ~$120k via pilots and AE/SE.
  - Target LTV > $600k/customer over 5 years with churn <8% and expansions.

Funding needs
